{{pp|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 2 Chainz | background = solo_singer <!-- includes rappers --> | image = File:2 Chainz at Pretty Girls Like Trap Music Tour.jpg | image_size=200px | caption = Epps in 2017 | birth_name = Tauheed Epps | alias = {{hlist|Tity Boi|Drenchgod}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1977|09|12}} | birth_place = [[College Park, Georgia]], U.S. | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = {{flatlist| * Rapper * songwriter * television personality * activist * actor }} | years_active = 1997–present | label = {{flatlist| * [[Def Jam Recordings|Def Jam]] * [[#The Real University|T.R.U.]] }} | associated_acts = <!-- Exercise constraint and add only the NOTABLE acts associated with 2 Chainz; see [[Template:Infobox musical artist#Associated acts]] for criteria --> {{flatlist| * [[Playaz Circle]] * [[Gucci Mane]] * [[Jeezy]] * [[Lil Wayne]] * [[Ludacris]] * [[Migos]] }} | website = {{url|http://www.2chainz.com}} }} '''Tauheed Epps''' (born September 12, 1977),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2012/09/13/video-2-chainz-gets-his-big-booty-birthday-wish/ |title=2 Chainz Gets His Big Booty Birthday Wish |website=Rap-Up.com|accessdate=June 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsagents.net/index.php/content/content17/176-2-chainz |title=2 Chainz |website=Sportsagents.net |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> known professionally as '''2 Chainz''' (formerly '''Tity Boi'''), is an American rapper, songwriter, television personality, activist, and actor. Born and raised in [[College Park, Georgia]], he initially gained recognition for being one-half of the [[Southern hip hop]] duo [[Playaz Circle]], alongside his longtime friend and fellow rapper Earl "Dolla Boy" Conyers. The duo was signed to fellow Georgia-based rapper [[Ludacris]]' [[Disturbing tha Peace]] label, and are best known for their debut single "[[Duffle Bag Boy]]".
In February 2012, Epps signed a solo [[record deal]] with [[Def Jam Recordings]], an imprint of [[Universal Music Group]]. The following August, he released his debut studio album ''[[Based on a T.R.U. Story]]'', to mixed reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/based-on-a-tru-story/2-chainz/critic-reviews |title=Critic Reviews for Based on a T.R.U. Story |website=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=November 20, 2012}}</ref> The album spawned three successful singles: "[[No Lie (2 Chainz song)|No Lie]]," "[[Birthday Song]]," and "[[I'm Different (2 Chainz song)|I'm Different]]", all of which charted in the top 50 of the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and were certified Gold or higher by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]], along with the album being certified Gold. His second studio album ''[[B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time]]'' was released on September 11, 2013. It was supported by the singles "[[Feds Watching]]" and "[[Used 2]]". Mr. Chainz began working with the TV Network [[Viceland]] on a show called [[Most Expensivest]], which debuted its first episode on November 15, 2017, and is currently in its second season.
==Early life and education== 2 Chainz was born '''Tauheed Epps''' in [[College Park, Georgia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/2-chainz-might-run-for-mayor-of-college-park-georgia-2015281|title=2 Chainz Might Run for Mayor of College Park, Georgia: Rapper Gets Political|website=Us Weekly|first=Madeline|last=Boardman|date=January 28, 2015|accessdate=November 8, 2016}}</ref> He attended [[North Clayton High School]], where he played basketball and graduated second in his class.<ref name=beast>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/03/27/2-chainz-is-no-donald-trump-fan.html|title=2 Chainz Is No Donald Trump Fan|website=The Daily Beast|first=Marlow|last=Stern|date=March 27, 2016|accessdate=November 8, 2016}}</ref> While in high school, he dealt [[marijuana]] and was arrested for felony [[cocaine]] possession when he was 15 years old.<ref name=beast/> He later attended [[Alabama State University]] on a scholarship, and played on its basketball team from 1995 to 1997.<ref name="sports-reference">{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cbb/players/tauheed-epps-1.html|title=Tauheed Epps|accessdate=July 4, 2017|work=S-R CBB}}</ref><ref name=espn>{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/playbooksounds/post/_/id/3120/how-good-was-2-chainz-at-basketball |website=espn.go.com |publisher=ESPN |title=How good was 2 Chainz at basketball? |accessdate=December 10, 2012}}</ref>
When asked by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' about longstanding rumors that he had graduated from Alabama State with a 4.0 GPA, which had been widely reported on many sources including [[Wikipedia]], 2 Chainz said: "Don't believe anything on Wack-ipedia. There's a lot of false stuff on there, to the point that every time I try to fix one thing, something else comes out."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/q-a-suddenly-2-chainz-is-everywhere-20120813 | title=Five Reasons Why 2 Chainz Should Make A Presidential Bid | work=The Observer | date=September 25, 2012 | accessdate=January 10, 2016 | author=Vanessa Quilantan}}</ref> In fact, he transferred to [[Virginia State University]] due to circumstances he was reluctant to speak about.<ref name=beast/> "I got into some trouble, went somewhere else, and came back. But I graduated, and that’s that. That was then," he said.<ref name=beast/>
==Career==
===1997–2010: Playaz Circle and Disturbing tha Peace=== Epps formed the hip hop duo [[Playaz Circle]] (the word "Playaz" being a [[bacronym]] for "Preparing Legal Assets for Years from A to Z")<ref name=dubmagazine>{{cite web|title=Playaz Circle|url=http://dubmagazine.com/stars/musicians/410-playaz-circle|work=Dub Magazine|publisher=Dub Publishing |accessdate=May 20, 2012}}</ref> in [[College Park, Georgia]] in 1997, with his high school friend Earl Conyers (known as Dolla Boy), while Epps adopted "Tity Boi" as his [[moniker]].<ref name=allmusicbio>{{cite web |last=Cordor|first=Cyril|title=Playaz Circle – Biography|url=http://allmusic.com/artist/playaz-circle-p733429/biography|work=[[Allmusic]]|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=May 20, 2012}}</ref> Following the release of an [[Independent music|independent album]] titled ''United We Stand, United We Fall'' (2002),<ref name=dubmagazine/> the duo were introduced to fellow Atlanta rapper [[Ludacris]], when he moved into their College Park apartment complex, whilst he was acting as a [[disc jockey|DJ]].<ref name=allmusicbio/> After taking interest in Playaz Circle, Ludacris began to record several songs with the group, playing some of them on his [[radio station]].<ref name=dubmagazine/>
Ludacris soon became one of the highest-selling rappers in the [[Southern United States]].<ref name=allmusicbio/> After hearing of their situation, Ludacris requested of Epps that the duo join his newly formed record label [[Disturbing Tha Peace]], a subsidiary of [[Def Jam Recordings]]. Epps agreed to sign, although Conyers did not officially join the label until his mother regained her health, a year after the initial signing.<ref name=allmusicbio/>
Their debut album ''[[Supply & Demand (Playaz Circle album)|Supply & Demand]]'', was released on October 30, 2007. The [[lead single]] and their debut single, "[[Duffle Bag Boy]]", became an urban [[hit single]]. The song features [[Lil Wayne]], and was performed by the duo at the [[BET Hip Hop Awards]]. The duo released their second studio album ''[[Flight 360: The Takeoff]]'', on September 29, 2009. In January 2010, Playaz Circle filmed a music video for their single "Big Dawg" [[featuring]] Lil Wayne and [[Birdman (entertainer)|Birdman]] at Studio Space Atlanta. Shortly afterwards, Epps left Disturbing tha Peace, a move he claimed was taken in order to advance his career. Although Ludacris was initially reluctant to allow Epps to leave the label (as he felt Epps could still prove financially successful), he eventually accepted the decision.<ref name=albumtitle>{{cite web|last=Vasquez|first=Andres|title=2 Chainz Reveals Album Title, Speaks On Leaving Ludacris' Label|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.19019/title.2-chainz-reveals-album-title-speaks-on-leaving-ludacris-label|work=HipHopDX|publisher=Cheri Media Group|accessdate=May 20, 2012|date=March 15, 2012}}</ref>
===2011–12: Name change and ''Based on a T.R.U. Story''=== [[File:2 Chainz 2014 May.jpg|210px|thumb|left|Epps in 2013]] Throughout Epps's career, critics and fans alike have speculated the [[pseudonym]] "Tity Boi" was meant to be derogatory towards women, although he repeatedly denied such accusations.<ref name=vibenamechange>{{cite web|title=2 Chainz Opens Up About Why He Was Named 'Tity Boi,' T.R.U. Realigion Mixtape, and his Use of Codeine Syrup. 2 Chainz also collaborated with 8 Rochester rapper "Dale Mahoney" on his mixtape "Jordans&Drugs" in 2012.|url=http://www.vibe.com/article/2-chainz-opens-about-why-he-was-named-tity-boi-tru-realigon-mixtape-and-his-use-codeine|work=[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]|publisher=Vibe Media|accessdate=May 20, 2012|date=October 27, 2011}}</ref> In early 2011, Epps decided to change his stage name to '''2 Chainz,''' as he perceived it to be more "family friendly."<ref name=hiphopdxnamechange>{{cite web|last=Harling|first=Danielle|title=2 Chainz Explains His Decision To Drop Tity Boi As A Stage Name, Says 2 Chainz Is More "Family Friendly"|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.18172/title.2-chainz-explains-his-decision-to-drop-tity-boi-as-a-stage-name-says-2-chainz-is-more-family-friendly|work=HipHopDX|publisher=Cheri Media Group|accessdate=May 20, 2012|date=January 3, 2012}}</ref> Following the name change, Epps released a [[mixtape]] entitled ''T.R.U. REALigion,'' which became his first mixtape to appear on the music charts, peaking at number 58 on the US ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums]] chart.<ref>{{cite web|title=2 Chainz – Charts & Awards – ''Billboard'' Albums|url=http://allmusic.com/artist/2-chainz-p2450987/charts-awards|work=Allmusic|publisher=Rovi Corporation|accessdate=May 20, 2012}}</ref> Since the success of the mixtape, Epps has made numerous [[guest appearance]]s on tracks by prominent recording artists such as<ref name=vibenamechange/> Kanye West ("[[Mercy (GOOD Music song)|Mercy]]") and Nicki Minaj ("[[Beez in the Trap]]").
On March 24, 2012, Epps announced his debut [[studio album]], whose title he had changed to ''[[Based on a T.R.U. Story]]'' from its original title of ''T.R.U. to My REALigion,''<ref name=albumtitle/> was set for an August 14, 2012, release date.<ref name=boombox>{{cite web|last=Bark|first=Theo|title=2 Chainz, 'Based on a T.R.U. Story': Rapper Reveals Producers on LP, Speaks on Kanye West|url=http://www.theboombox.com/2012/04/03/2-chainz-kanye-west|work=The Boombox|publisher=[[AOL]]|accessdate=May 20, 2012|date=April 3, 2012}}</ref> The album's lead single, "[[No Lie (2 Chainz song)|No Lie]]," features Canadian rapper [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]], and was released on May 8, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=No Lie (feat. Drake) – Single by 2 Chainz|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/no-lie-feat.-drake-single/id524552884|work=[[iTunes Store]]|publisher=[[Apple Inc.|Apple]]|accessdate=May 20, 2012}}</ref> On May 11, it was under speculation that Epps had signed to Kanye West's [[GOOD Music]] label, after West [[Twitter|tweeted]]: "2 Chainz is charging 100k for a verse now cause he's G.O.O.D!!!!!"<ref name=twitter>{{cite web |last=West |first=Kanye |title= 2 Chainz is charging 100k for a verse now cause he's G.O.O.D!!!!! |url=https://twitter.com/kanyewest/status/201078576676749312|work=Twitter |publisher=[[Twitter]] |accessdate=May 27, 2012 |date=May 11, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120710080218/http://twitter.com/kanyewest/status/201078576676749312|archivedate=July 10, 2012 }}</ref> However, Epps later denied those rumors, saying: "He just said I’m good, like I’m ill. But we was talking and I think I was jeopardizing my brand sometimes by doing the homeboy special. So I think he felt like we should just put that out there that we ain't doing no more of that."<ref>{{cite web|last=Horowitz |first=Steven J. |title=2 Chainz Responds To G.O.O.D. Music Signing Rumors |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.19725/title.2-chainz-responds-to-good-music-signing-rumors |website=HipHop DX |date=May 12, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Cofr7i3d?url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.19725/title.2-chainz-responds-to-good-music-signing-rumors |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |deadurl=no |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> On May 30, 2012, [[Ciara]] revealed 2 Chainz was featured on "[[Sweat (Ciara song)|Sweat]]," the intended first single from her fifth studio album, ''[[Jackie (Ciara album)|One Woman Army]].''<ref>{{cite web|title=Ciara Announces New Album ''One Woman Army''|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2012/05/15/ciara-announces-new-album-one-woman-army-first-single-sweat/#more-125650|work=|website=[[Rap-Up]].com |accessdate=May 30, 2012}}</ref>
''Based on a T.R.U. Story'' debuted at number one on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], selling 147,000 copies in its first week.<ref name="Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 8/19/2012">{{cite web|last=Vazquez|first=Edwin|title=Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 8/19/2012|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.20875/title.hip-hop-album-sales-the-week-ending-8-19-2012|publisher=Cheri Media Group|accessdate=August 22, 2012}}</ref> The album was met with mixed reviews, earning a score of 55 on [[metacritic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/based-on-a-tru-story/2-chainz/critic-reviews |title=Critic Reviews for Based on a T.R.U. Story |website=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> As of September 23, 2012, the album has sold 288,000 copies in the United States.<ref name="Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 9/23/2012">{{cite web|last=Paine|first=Jack|title=Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 9/23/2012 |website=HipHopDX |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.21300/title.hip-hop-album-sales-the-week-ending-9-23-2012|publisher=Cheri Media Group|accessdate=September 26, 2012}}</ref> In September, Epps performed at the [[2012 MTV Video Music Awards]], alongside longtime friend [[Lil Wayne]]. After the release of his debut, ''Based on a T.R.U. Story,'' Epps made momentous strides. He facilitated his first solo worldwide tour, selling out most of its dates; he was nominated for over 13 [[BET Hip Hop Awards]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Murphy|first=Keith|title=Editor|url=http://v103.cbslocal.com/2012/10/10/kanye-west-2-chainz-kendrick-lamar-among-winners-at-bet-hip-hop-awards/|website=CBS Local}}</ref> bringing home 4 such trophies;<ref>{{cite web |last=Markman |first=Rob |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1695223/kanye-west-2-chainz-bet-hip-hop-awards-winners-list.jhtml |website=mtv.com |publisher=MTV News |title=2012 BET Hip Hop Awards Belong To Kanye West, 2 Chainz |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CofUX5sW?url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1695223/kanye-west-2-chainz-bet-hip-hop-awards-winners-list.jhtml |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> he earned ''The Source'' Magazine’s "Man of the Year" award;<ref>{{cite web|last=Fitzgerald |first=Trent |url=http://popcrush.com/2-chainz-man-of-the-year-the-source-magazine/ |website=Popcrush |title=2 Chainz Crowned Man Of the Year by The Source Magazine |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Cog88Ltt?url=http://popcrush.com/2-chainz-man-of-the-year-the-source-magazine/ |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> he released a collaborative endeavor with ADIDAS,<ref>{{cite web|last=Crates |first=Jake |url=http://allhiphop.com/2012/11/21/2-chainz-featured-in-champs-sports-commericials-and-facebook-digital-game-for-adidas-originals/ |website=AllHipHop |title=2 Chainz Featured in Champs Sports Commercials and Facebook Digital Game for Adidas Originals |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CogIrmvk?url=http://allhiphop.com/2012/11/21/2-chainz-featured-in-champs-sports-commericials-and-facebook-digital-game-for-adidas-originals/ |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> and later Beats By Dre;<ref>{{cite web |last=Kathiya |first=Henna |url=http://rapfix.mtv.com/2012/11/21/2-chainz-azealia-banks-lil-wayne-and-more-star-in-beats-by-dre-ad/ |website=MTV RapFix |title=2 Chainz, Azealia Banks, Lil Wayne And More Star In Beats By Dre Ad |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CogSRorc?url=http://rapfix.mtv.com/2012/11/21/2-chainz-azealia-banks-lil-wayne-and-more-star-in-beats-by-dre-ad/ |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> and he was nominated for three [[Grammy Awards]], including Best Rap Album.<ref>{{cite web |last=Watson |first=Andrew |url=http://theversed.com/2012/12/10/2-chainz-discusses-grammy-nomination-for-rap-album-of-the-year-thanks-kanye-west-and-drake/ |website=The Versed |title=2 Chainz Discusses Grammy Nomination For Rap Album Of The Year, Thanks Kanye West And Drake |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CogaPVXo?url=http://theversed.com/2012/12/10/2-chainz-discusses-grammy-nomination-for-rap-album-of-the-year-thanks-kanye-west-and-drake/ |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
===2012–15: ''B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time'' and ''Collegrove''=== {{Main|B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time|ColleGrove}} [[File:2 Chainz May 2014 2 (cropped).jpg|200px|right|thumb|2 Chainz performing in 2014]] In late 2012, Epps stated once he completed the [[Based on a T.R.U. Story|B.O.A.T.S.]] concert tour, he would reenter the studio. In November 2012, he revealed he was three songs deep into his second studio album. The album's estimated release date was April 2013.<ref name="www.hiphopdx.com">{{cite web | last = | first = | title = 2 Chainz Has Three Songs Recorded For Sophomore LP | url = http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.21735/title.2-chainz-has-three-songs-recorded-for-sophomore-lp | website=HipHopDX | date = | accessdate = November 2, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/features/2013/01/xxl-presents-the-35-most-anticipated-albums-of-2013-3/#18 |title=XXL Presents... The 35 Most Anticipated Albums of 2013 – XXL |work=Xxlmag.com |date=January 14, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> The rapper made a guest appearance on [[NBC]]'s ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' in an episode that aired May 8, 2013.<ref name="past">{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2013/04/09/law-and-order-svu-season-14-cast-kathryn-erbe/|title=''Law & Order: SVU'' Exclusive: Kathryn Erbe Returns for 'Big' Fin Episode|work=TVLine.com|accessdate=April 9, 2013}}</ref> He also appeared as himself in the second season (episode 16, titled "...And Just Plane Magic") of the [[CBS]] sitcom ''[[2 Broke Girls]],'' where he travels on the same private planes as the two main characters.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.22638/title.2-chainz-guest-stars-on-2-broke-girls- |title=2 Chainz Guest Stars On "2 Broke Girls" |accessdate=May 17, 2013 |website=www.hiphopdx.com}}</ref> On May 23, 2013, he announced that his second studio album ''[[B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time]]'' will be released on September 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Paine |first=Jake |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.24073/title.2-chainz-announces-sophomore-solo-album-release-date/ |title=2 Chainz "B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time" Release Date, Tracklist & Production Credits | Get The Latest Hip Hop News, Rap News & Hip Hop Album Sales |website=HipHop DX|date=August 22, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> On June 2, 2013, Epps premiered the first single from the album, titled "Feds Watching," at the [[WQHT|Hot 97]]'s Summer Jam. The song featured [[Pharrell Williams]], and it was recorded on 2013 Grammy Awards night.<ref>{{cite web|last=Langhorne |first=Cyrus |url=http://www.sohh.com/2013/06/2_chainz_has_the_feds_watching_at_summer.html |title=2 Chainz Has The "Feds Watching" At Summer Jam [Video |website=Sohh.Com |date=June 3, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com/article/exclusive-pharrell-making-2-chainz-feds-watching-single |title=Exclusive: Pharrell On the Making Of 2 Chainz 'Feds Watching' Single |website=Vibe |date=June 5, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> On June 15, Epps announced the title of his second album would be ''B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/06/2-chainz-boats-ii-drake-hot-1079-atlanta-birthday-bash |title=2 Chainz B.O.A.T.S. II and Drake at Hot 107.9 Atlanta Birthday Bash |website=Complex |date= |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> The album was released, through Def Jam Recordings, on September 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2013/09/2-chainz-pissed-amount-albums-shipped/ |title=2 Chainz Is Pissed At The Amount Of Copies His Album Shipped – XXL |work=Xxlmag.com |date=September 10, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref>
''B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time'' featured [[guest appearance]]s from [[Pharrell Williams]], [[Fergie (singer)|Fergie]], Drake, [[Lil Wayne]], [[Pusha T]], [[Mase]], [[Chrisette Michele]], [[Iamsu!]], [[T-Pain]], Dolla Boy, [[Rich Homie Quan]], and [[Lloyd (singer)|Lloyd]] among others. The album's [[Record production|production]] was handled by [[Diplo]], [[Mike WiLL Made It]], [[Drumma Boy]], [[J.U.S.T.I.C.E. League]], [[Mannie Fresh]], Wonder Arillo, Da Honorable C-Note and [[DJ Toomp]] among others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2013/08/22/tracklisting-2-chainz-boats-2-me-time/ |title=Tracklisting: 2 Chainz – ‘B.O.A.T.S. 2 #MEtime’ |website=Rap-Up.com |date=August 22, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> It was also supported by the single "Used 2," along with the [[promotional single]]s "[[Where U Been? (song)|Where U Been?]]" and "Netflix." Upon the album's release, it was met with generally positive reviews from [[music critic]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/boats-ii-metime/2-chainz |title=B.O.A.T.S. II: #METIME Reviews |website=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> It also faired decently commercially, debuting at number three on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], and number two on the [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums]] chart selling 63,000 copies in its first week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5695587/keith-urban-edges-the-weeknd-for-no-1-debut-on-billboard-200 |title=Keith Urban Edges the Weeknd for No. 1 Debut on Billboard 200 |work=Billboard |date=December 1, 2012 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref>
On October 23, 2013, Epps revealed that he had begun working on his third studio album immediately following the release of ''B.O.A.T.S. II''. He also stated he had the first single from his third album ready for release and that he still wanted to get [[Jay-Z]] featured on the album.<ref>{{cite web|author=*Please enter your name. |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2013/10/2-chainz-working-third-album/ |title=Xxlmag.com |work=Xxlmag.com |date=October 26, 2013 |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> In November 2015, 2 Chainz revealed that he was releasing a joint album with [[Lil Wayne]], titled ''[[ColleGrove]].''<ref>{{cite web|title = 2 Chainz Announces Next Solo Album & Joint Project With Lil Wayne|url = http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/2-chainz-announces-next-solo-album-and-joint-project-with-lil-wayne-news.18632.html?image=1&gallery=0|website = HotNewHipHop|access-date = February 22, 2016}}</ref> On May 5, 2014, Epps released a brand new EP titled ''FreeBase'' for free digital download. It includes 7 songs, and includes features from [[Lil Boosie]], [[A$AP Rocky]], [[Rick Ross]] and more. The EP has earned over 200,000 downloads.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.datpiff.com/2-Chainz-FreeBase-mixtape.608133.html |title=Datpiff.com |website=Datpiff.com |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> In January 2014 Epps released a promotional single titled "I'm A Dog."
===2016–present: ''Pretty Girls Like Trap Music'' & Rap Or Go To The League=== {{Main|Pretty Girls Like Trap Music}} On January 27, 2016 Epps released an EP titled "Felt Like Cappin" the EP was released via online streaming sites and [[iTunes]], the EP is promoted by the single "Back On That Bullshit" featuring [[Lil Wayne]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://listen.tidal.com/album/56705198 |title=TIDAL |website=Listen.tidal.com |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref>
Epps began 2016 with the March release of a 12 record collaborative album with rapper [[Lil Wayne]] titled ''[[ColleGrove]]''. The album was supposed to be the debut LP between 2 Chainz and [[Lil Wayne]], however, Wayne’s ongoing lawsuit with [[Cash Money Records]] prevented Wayne from being a primary artist on the album. Epps appears as the primary artist on the album with eight tracks featuring [[Lil Wayne]]. The album features prominent producers such as: [[Honorable C.N.O.T.E.]], [[Mike Will Made It]], [[Zaytoven]], [[TM88]], [[Metro Boomin]], [[London on da Track]], and more. ''[[ColleGrove]]'' received decent reviews from critics and fans.
Epps continued his work in 2016 with the August 5, release of mixtape ''[[Daniel Son; Necklace Don]]'', currently a 9 track mixtape that Epps released independently. ''[[Daniel Son; Necklace Don]]'' originally featured [[Drake (musician)|Drake]] and [[YFN Lucci]] on it but Epps chose to move the song, "Big Amount ft. Drake" to 2017 studio album ''[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music]]'' due to its mass appeal on the mixtape and star power performance. ''[[Daniel Son; Necklace Don]]'' received a 3 out of 5 stars review from [[XXL (magazine)|XXL Magazine]].
2016 was wrapped up by Epps third mixtape titled ''[[Hibachi for Lunch]]'', released October 28. The seven track mixtape originally featured [[Quavo]], [[Gucci Mane]], [[Ty Dolla Sign]], and [[Future (rapper)|Future]] however, the song, "Good Drank ft. [[Quavo]] and [[Gucci Mane]]" was moved to ''[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music]]''. Notable production was done by: [[Mike Will Made It]], K Swisha, Buddah Bless.
In 2017 Epps released his fourth studio album titled ''[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music]]'' on June 16 by [[Def Jam Recordings]]. The album features [[Travis Scott]], [[Nicki Minaj]], [[Swae Lee]], [[Migos]], [[Jhené Aiko|Jhene Aiko]], [[Pharrell Williams]], and more. Album production was done by [[Mike Will Made It]], Buddah Bless, [[Mike Dean (record producer)|Mike Dean]], [[Murda Beatz]], and more. The album was supported by three official [[Single (music)|singles]]: "[[Good Drank]]", "[[It's a Vibe]]" and "4 AM". The album was also supported by a nationwide concert tour, as well as several [[Pop-up retail|pop-up shops]] in the US.<sup>[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music#cite note-1|[1]]] [[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music#cite note-2|[2]]]</sup> 2 Chainz alluded to the album showing "growth and maturation." He stated the content would maintain its edginess while also elevating [[Trap music (hip hop)|trap music]] to a point where everyone can appreciate it. ''Pretty Girls Like Trap Music'' received widespread critical acclaim, with most critics citing the album as his best album yet.
On November 15, 2017, the first episode of [[Most Expensivest]] aired on the TV network [[Viceland]]. The show focuses on 2 Chainz visiting different locations offering the "most expensivest" goods and services. Each show covers a particular theme, with shows ranging from personal health to extravagant indulgences. The show offers a unique insight into products and services that have been created with the explicit intent on being exclusive and expensive. 2 Chainz offers a unique, and often humorous insight into the products, especially the ones he personally finds to be either amazing or ridiculous. The show has been renewed for a 20-episode third season set to air in early 2019.<ref>https://premieredate.news/tv-series/4568-most-expensivest.html</ref>
[[The Play Don't Care Who Makes It|''The Play Don’t Care Who Makes'']] It is the fourth EP released by Epps on February 8, 2018, by [[Def Jam Recordings]]. The EP consists of four songs one of which features appearances from [[YG (rapper)|YG]] and [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] on the song "PROUD". Production was done by Minus, June James, Nonstop, Streetrunner, and more.
On February 19, 2018 Epps announced his new album Rap Or Go To The League which is set to be released in 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8208245/2-chainz-announces-new-album-rap-or-go-to-the-league|title=2 Chainz Announces New Album 'Rap or Go to the League'|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref>
==Personal life==
===Family=== Epps has two daughters, Heaven and Harmony.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.papermag.com/2015/05/2_chainz_legalization_voting_rights_fatherhood.php |title=2 Chainz Talks Legalization, Voting Rights & Fatherhood |website=Papermag |date=May 4, 2015 |accessdate=July 24, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://hiphopdx.com/news/id.25929/title.2-chainz-reveals-whether-he-lets-his-children-listen-to-his-music |title=2 Chainz Reveals Whether He Lets His Children Listen To His Music |website=HipHop DX |date=October 22, 2013 |accessdate=July 24, 2015}}</ref> On October 14, 2015, 2 Chainz welcomed his third child, a baby boy named Halo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ballerstatus.com/2015/10/15/2-chainz-welcomes-third-child-a-baby-boy/ |title=2 Chainz Welcomes Third Child: A Baby Boy |website=BallerStatus.com |date=October 15, 2015}}</ref> On August 18, 2018, Epps married his longtime girlfriend and mother of his three children: Kesha Ward.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Pasquini |first1=Maria |title=2 Chainz Marries Longtime Love Kesha Ward in Miami Ceremony (with the Wests in Attendance!) |url=https://people.com/music/2-chainz-marries-kesha-ward/ |website=People |accessdate=28 August 2018 |date=August 18, 2018}}</ref>
===Legal issues=== At the age of 15, Epps was convicted of [[felony]] [[cocaine]] possession.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/07/2-chainz-breakfast-club-interview |title=2 Chainz Breakfast Club Interview |website=Complex |date=July 25, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> On February 14, 2013, Epps was arrested in [[Maryland]] en route to a concert at [[University of Maryland Eastern Shore|UMES]] for [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuana]] possession. Epps was then cited and released.<ref>{{cite news|title=2 Chainz Arrested in Maryland on Marijuana Charge|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/2-chainz-arrested-in-maryland-on-marijuana-charge-20130215|newspaper=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=February 15, 2013<!-- 1:35 PM-->}}</ref>
On June 11, 2013, Epps was arrested while on board a departing flight at [[LAX]] airport for possession of a controlled substance after TSA agents found that his checked bag contained [[marijuana]] and [[promethazine]]. He was booked and charged with [[felony]] narcotics possession. Later that day he posted $10,000 bond and was released. He was due back in court on June 21, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2013/06/2-chainz-arrested-in-lax-for-possession-of-marijuana-and-promethazine/ |title=2 Chainz Arrested In LAX For Possession Of Marijuana And Promethazine – XXL |work=Xxlmag.com |date=June 11, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> Two days previous, he was reportedly robbed at gunpoint outside a [[medical marijuana]] dispensary in [[San Francisco]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Rapper 2 Chainz robbed outside S.F. marijuana dispensary|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/crime/2013/06/10/rapper-2-chainz-robbed-outside-s-f-marijuana-dispensary/|agency=Associated Press|website=SFGate.com|accessdate=June 27, 2013|date=June 10, 2013}}</ref>
Just before midnight on August 21, 2013, Epps' tour bus was pulled over in [[Oklahoma City|Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]], because the passenger side taillights were out. The arresting officer reported that he smelled marijuana and saw smoke through the open door of the bus after he had stopped and pulled over the bus. The driver of the bus shut the door and told officers he was not authorized to allow them on the bus. The officer said the [[marijuana]] smell gave him probable cause to search, but the driver refused to open the door. After many attempts to enter, the bus was towed with the men still aboard to the police training center in Oklahoma City. Officers obtained a search warrant and the 10 men, including Epps, got off the bus. Police discovered two semi-automatic pistols and a 12-gauge pump shotgun, along with some prescription painkillers and marijuana residue, on the tour bus according to papers filed [[Oklahoma County, Oklahoma|Oklahoma County]] district Court.<ref>{{cite web|author=MICHAEL MCNUTT mmcnutt@opubco.com • |url=http://newsok.com/oklahoma-city-police-found-weapons-painkillers-on-rappers-tour-bus-court-papers-show/article/3878935 |title=Oklahoma City police found weapons, painkillers on rapper's tour bus, court papers show |website=News OK |date=September 3, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref>
==Business ventures==
In October 2016, he opened a line of hoodies called CEO Millionaires or Create Every Opportunity Millionaires.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/2-chainz-releases-new-line-of-ceo-millionaires-hoodies-news.24735.html? |title=2 Chainz releases line of hoodies |last=Goddard |first=Kevin |date=October 14, 2016 |website=[[Hotnewhiphop]] |access-date=October 14, 2016}}</ref> He also has his own line of sweaters called "Dabbing Sweaters."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/2-chainz-reveals-new-line-of-dabbing-santa-sweaters-news.25560.html? |title=2 Chainz releases line of sweaters called "Dabbin Sweaters"|last=Goddard |first=Kevin |date=November 19, 2016 |website=[[Hotnewhiphop]] |access-date=November 19, 2016}}</ref>

II: Me Time]]'' (2013) * ''[[ColleGrove]]'' (2016) * ''[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music]]'' (2017) * ''Rap or Go to the League'' (2018)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2018/02/2-chainz-announces-next-album-rap-or-go-to-the-league|title=2 Chainz Announces His Next Album 'Rap or Go to the League'|work=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|last=Elder|first=Sajae|date=February 17, 2018|accessdate=February 18, 2018}}</ref>

On January 6, 2015, 2 Chainz announced that he was starting his own independent record label "The Real University" (also known as "T.R.U."; or "The Real U").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thesource.com/2015/01/06/2-chainz-announces-the-real-university-label-with-mix-tape-tru-jack-city/ |title=2 Chainz Announces The Real University Label With Mix-tape "Tru Jack City" |website=The Source |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=*Please enter your name. |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/new-music/2015/01/2-chainz-featuring-cap-1-young-dolph-trap-house-stalkin/ |title=2 Chainz Featuring Cap 1 And Young Dolph "Trap House Stalkin" – XXL |work=Xxlmag.com |date=January 6, 2015 |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> The announcement also revealed that frequent collaborators Cap.1 & Skooly were signed. Additionally, they signed former [[Young Money]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youngmoneyhq.com/artists/short-dawg/ |title=Short Dawg | Young Money Artist |website=Youngmoneyhq.com |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=<!-- author name --> Amir Diamond <!-- post timestamp --> |url=http://theboxhouston.com/9521719/find-out-why-short-dawg-aka-freh-is-no-longer-with-young-money/ |title=Find Out Why Short Dawg aka Fre$h Is No Longer With Young Money!! | 97.9 The Box |website=Theboxhouston.com |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> artist Short Dawg, who is now known as Fresh. Along with the announcement of the label's founding, they also revealed they'd be releasing their debut mixtape ''TRU Jack City'' on January 27, 2015.

'''Aakanksha Bhargava''' (born 1985) is an Indian entrepreneur, and is currently{{when?|date=October 2018}} the only woman leading a large [[relocation service|relocation]] business in India.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Lady CEO expands her feet in relocation business |url=http://www.aninews.in/videogallery2/43677-lady-ceo-expands-her-feet-in-relocation-business.html |work=[[Asian News International]] |accessdate=2015-12-03 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> She is the [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] and President of PM Relocations Pvt Ltd (PMR) in [[Gurgaon]].
== Early life and education == Bhargava was born in [[Kolkata]] and later moved to [[Delhi]] in 1992. She studied at [[Tagore International School]] in Vasant Vihar, Delhi and later completed her B.Com Honours from [[Hindu College, University of Delhi|Hindu College]]. After this she went to Singapore and [[Dubai]] for further studies and completed her master's degree, [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] in Marketing from [[S P Jain School of Global Management]], Singapore and Dubai.<ref>{{Cite web|title = A Mover And Shaker In The Relocation Sector {{!}} mindyourbusiness.in|url = http://www.mindyourbusiness.in/articles/1003835/a-mover-and-shaker-in-the-relocation-sector|website = www.mindyourbusiness.in|accessdate = 2015-12-03}}</ref>
== Career == Bhargava joined PMR on 30 April 2007. Initially she was a manager in international sales, then moved on to handling corporate sales, marketing, operations and other verticals for the company. She was promoted to CEO in 2012. In 2015 she was awarded "Best Women Leader" by the Business Today Awards in the Small & Medium Enterprise segment.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Change Manager: PM Relocations- Business News|url = http://www.businesstoday.in/magazine/special/india-best-smes-winners-2015-pm-relocations-aakanksha-bhargava/story/223929.html|website = Business Today India|accessdate = 2015-12-03|date = 11 October 2015}}</ref> She was recognized for her contribution towards the entrepreneurship report submitted on behalf of PMR by [[Indian School of Business]](ISB).{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} She is also an elected member of [[PAIMA]] and IAM’s board panel.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
Bhargava opened new branches of the company in [[Bangalore]], [[Hyderabad]], [[Pune]], [[Ahmedabad]], [[Mumbai]] and [[Chennai]]. With this the company has also grown in numbers, global contracts and people.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Leading the way in the male-dominated relocation industry|url = http://mybigplunge.com/start-up/aakanksha-bhargava/|website = My Big Plunge|publisher = mybigplunge.com|accessdate = 2015-12-03|language = en-US}}</ref> During her tenure as the CEO of PMR, the company has grown from a top line of Rs 2 crore in 2010 to nearly Rs 46 crore in 2015.<ref name=":0" />
She has written articles for the education portal ''Education Insider'',<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bringing professionalism to an unorganised sector|url = http://www.educationinsider.net/detail_news.php?id=2358|website = www.educationinsider.net|accessdate = 2015-12-03}}</ref> MindYourBusiness<ref>{{Cite web|title = Dancing Is A Liberating Experience: Aakanksha Bhargava {{!}} mindyourbusiness.in|url = http://www.mindyourbusiness.in/articles/1003359/dancing-is-a-liberating-experience-aakanksha-bhargava#sthash.ypjiGbsG.dpuf|website = www.mindyourbusiness.in|accessdate = 2015-12-03}}</ref> and for the [[Indo-German Chamber of Commerce]].
== Awards and recognition== * Awarded as Women Of Worth- - By [https://www.outlookbusiness.com/specials/women-of-worth_2017 Outlook Business Magazine] * Best Woman Leader - [[Business Today (business magazine)|Business Today]] SME Awards 2015.<ref name=":0" /> * Woman Entrepreneur of The Year - Franchise India Awards 2016.<ref name=":0" /> * Won 'People Management Approach by an FMB' by SPJIMR Family Managed Business Awards 2017 <ref name=":0" /> * Nominated for the 'Entrepreneur of the Year in Service Business - SCM & Logistics' at the 7th Annual Entrepreneur India Awards <ref name=":0" /> * Nominated for the 10th IWEC Awards 2017 <ref name=":0" />

'''''Age of Lone Wolf Terrorism''''' is a 2017 book about [[Lone wolf (terrorism)|lone wolf terrorism]] co-authored by Mark Hamm, a criminologist at [[Indiana State University]] and Ramon Spaaij, a sociologist at [[Victoria University, Australia]].
According to a review in [[Times Higher Education]] that described ''Age of Lone Wolf Terrorism'' as an "genuinely indispensable study of today’s steadily increasing terrorist threat," the book's "pivotal contention" that the radicalization of lone wolf terrorists exhibits discernible patterns that include “the integration of personal and political grievances; an affinity with online sympathizers and/or extremist groups," and "triggering events that, oftentimes, cause a dramatic change in behavior”.<ref name="FeldmanReview">{{cite news|last1=Feldman|first1=Matthew|title=The Age of Lone Wolf Terrorism (book review)|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/books/review-the-age-of-lone-wolf-terrorism-mark-s-hamm-and-ramon-spaaij-columbia-university-press#survey-answer|accessdate=14 March 2018|publisher=Times Higher Education|date=15 June 2017}}</ref>
Hamm and Spaaij constructed a database funded by the United States Department of Justice in which they identified 124 instances of [[lone wolf (terrorism)|lone wolf terrorist]] attacks in the United States between 1940 and 2016; the list includes "about" 30 planned attacks that are known not to have been carrier out, or that have been identified as FBI [[sting operation]]s, or as hoaxes.<ref name="DeadlyWorth">{{cite news|last1=Worth|first1=Katie|title=Lone Wolf Attacks Are Becoming More Common — And More Deadly|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/article/lone-wolf-attacks-are-becoming-more-common-and-more-deadly/|accessdate=14 March 2018|publisher=PBS Frontline|date=14 July 2016}}</ref> Hamm and Spaaij defined lone wolf terrorism narrowly; they required an attacker to be politically motivated, this excluded, for example, mass shooters such as Adam Lanza, whose motive appeared to be entirely personal. And they had to have acted entirely alone, excluding cases like the [[2015 San Bernardino attack]] carried out by a married couple, and the [[Boston Marathon bombing]], carried out by a pair of brothers.<ref name="DeadlyWorth"/><ref name="BojaniOne">{{cite news|last1=Bojani|first1=Fatima|title=America’s lone-wolf terrorists are unpredictable in almost every regard—except one|url=https://qz.com/807997/lone-wolf-terrorists-gun-control-us/|accessdate=14 March 2018|publisher=Quartz|date=19 October 2016}}</ref><ref name=MillettReview> Kris Millett (2017): Hamm & Spaaij ’s The Age of Lone Wolf Terrorism and the prospect of a heterodox terrorism studies (book review), Critical Studies on Terrorism, DOI:10.1080/17539153.2017.1384154</ref> Kris Millett (2017): Hamm & Spaaij’s The Age of Lone Wolf Terrorism and the prospect of a heterodox terrorism studies (book review), Critical Studies on Terrorism, DOI:10.1080/17539153.2017.1384154</ref><ref name=MisReview/><ref name=SinaiReview/>. The tightness of this definition was widely criticized.<ref name=MisReview/><ref name=SinaiReview/><ref name="BojaniOne"/>
==Findings== Hamm and Spaaij use data they compiled, and examinations of the lone wolf phenomenon by other researches to reach a series of conclusions.<ref name="DeadlyWorth"/><ref name="BojaniOne"/>
They conclude that lone wolf terrorist attacks are becoming more common in the United States, and that casualty tolls, both of injuries and of deaths, has risen steadily over the decades since 1940, and risen sharply in the 2010s. They note that the lone wolf terrorist who killed the highest number of victims was [[Joseph Paul Franklin]] who carried out a series of attacks in which he targeted [[Black people|black]] and [[Jewish]] Americans.<ref name="DeadlyWorth"/> They also show that in recent years lone wolves have more frequently targeted uniformed police and military personnel.<ref name=MillettReview/>
They conclude that although as of 2018, [[white supremacist]] ideologies continue to account for the largest share of attacks, but that [[jihadist]] motivation has risen rapidly.<ref name="DeadlyWorth"/>
They conclude that lone wolf terrorists are usually unemployed, single, white males with a criminal record who tend to be older, to have less education, and more likely to have a record of mental illness than other violent criminals.<ref name="DeadlyWorth"/> In particularly, they demonstrate that in recent years such recent attacks have followed incidents in which the lone wolf uses physical violence against women.
Their data demonstrates that although explosives and guns were the most common weapons used by lone wolves from the 1940s through the 1980s, the use of guns has skyrocketed and they are now the weapon most commonly employed by lone wolf terrorists.<ref name="DeadlyWorth"/><ref name="BojaniOne"/>
They show that most lone wolves tell someone that they intend to carry out an attack. From the 1940s through the end of the century 84% of lone wolves did so, since 76% have done so.<ref name="DeadlyWorth"/>
==Criticism of law enforcement== Hamm and Spaaij single out FBI sting operations for special criticism. Book reviewer Kris Millett praises their "devastatingly effective" use of data to "argue that those captured in the sting operations did not display the personal characteristics common to the radicalisation of lone wolf terrorists."<ref name=MillettReview/>
==Reception== Reviewer James Mills criticizes Hamm and Spaaij for using narrow criteria that eliminate lone wolf pairs such as [[Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik]] and the [[Tsarnaev brothers]] from inclusion on their list, even those they meet the definition in all other ways. Mills also criticized their argument that lone wolf terrorism is preventable since “violent radicalization is a social process involving behavior that can be observed, comprehended and modeled,” arguing that the influences on human action are complex and not easily modeled and predicted, while praising the author's date gathering.<ref name=MisReview> Mis, James, Mark. S. Hamm, and Ramón Spaaij. PRISM 7, no. 3 (2018): 134-35. https://www.jstor.org/stable/26470541</ref>
Reviewer Joshua Sinai points out that lone wolves may regard themselves as members of terrorist organizations on the grounds that they are carrying out orders broadcast on the internet by the leaders of such organizations, and argues that, pace Hamm and Spaaij, FBI "sting" operations have been effective in preventing terrorism, but praises the author's six-part model (p. 159 in book,) of personal and political grievance, affinity with online sympathizers or an extremist group, enabler, broadcasting intent, triggering event, and engaging in terrorism (p. 159).<ref name=SinaiReview> Sinai, Joshua, Mark S. Hamm, and Ramon Spaaij. Perspectives on Terrorism 11, no. 3 (2017): 81. http://www.jstor.org/stable/26297850.</ref>

Mortimer (by marriage)
Charleton (by marriage) |}} '''Alianore Holland, Countess of March''' (also spelt '''Eleanor'''; 13 October 1370 – October 1405) was the eldest daughter of [[Thomas Holland, 2nd Earl of Kent]], and the wife of [[Roger Mortimer, 4th Earl of March]], [[heir presumptive]] to her uncle, King [[Richard II of England|Richard II]]. Through her daughter, [[Anne de Mortimer|Anne Mortimer]], she was the great-grandmother of the [[Yorkist]] kings [[Edward IV of England|Edward IV]] and [[Richard III of England|Richard III]]. She was Governess to Queen consort [[Isabella of Valois]]. ==Family== Alianore Holland was born 13 October 1370{{Harvnb|Richardson III|2011|p=195}}. in [[Upholland]], Lancashire, the eldest child of [[Thomas Holland, 2nd Earl of Kent]], and [[Alice Holland, Countess of Kent|Lady Alice FitzAlan]], the daughter of [[Richard Fitzalan, 10th Earl of Arundel|Richard de Arundel, 10th Earl of Arundel]], and his second wife, [[Eleanor of Lancaster]], daughter of [[Henry, 3rd Earl of Lancaster]], grandson of [[Henry III of England|King Henry III]].{{Harvnb|Richardson III|2011|p=195}}; {{Harvnb|Richardson II|2011|pp=496–8}}. Her paternal grandparents were [[Thomas Holland, 1st Earl of Kent]], and [[Joan of Kent]], mother of King [[Richard II of England|Richard II]] by her third marriage to [[Edward, the Black Prince]]. As such, Alianore's father was a maternal half-brother to King Richard II. Alianore had four brothers and six sisters:{{Harvnb|Richardson II|2011|pp=497–500}}. *[[Thomas Holland, 1st Duke of Surrey]], who married Joan Stafford, daughter of [[Hugh de Stafford, 2nd Earl of Stafford]] *John Holland (born 2 November 1374) *Richard Holland (3 April 1376 – 21 May 1396) *[[Edmund Holland, 4th Earl of Kent]], who was reportedly betrothed to [[Constance of York]], widow of [[Thomas le Despenser, 1st Earl of Gloucester]], and who married Lucy Visconti, youngest daughter of [[Bernabò Visconti]] *Joan Holland, who married firstly, [[Edmund of Langley, 1st Duke of York]]; secondly, William Willoughby, 5th Lord Willoughby; thirdly, [[Henry Scrope, 3rd Baron Scrope of Masham]]; and fourthly, Henry Bromflete, Baron Vescy. *Eleanor Holland (the second of that name), who married [[Thomas Montacute, 4th Earl of Salisbury|Thomas Montagu, 4th Earl of Salisbury]] *Margaret Holland, who married firstly, [[John Beaufort, 1st Earl of Somerset]], and secondly, [[Thomas of Lancaster, Duke of Clarence]] *Elizabeth Holland, who married Sir John Neville of Sutton (in Gualtres), [[Yorkshire]] *Anne Holland (b. 4 December 1389) *Bridget (a nun) ==Marriages and issue== [[Edmund Mortimer, 3rd Earl of March]], had died in 1381, leaving a 6-year-old son, Roger Mortimer, as heir to the vast Mortimer estates. According to Davies, the wardship of such an important heir was an 'issue of political moment in the years 1382–4', and eventually Mortimer's lands were granted to a consortium for £4000 per annum, and the guardianship of his person was initially granted to [[Richard Fitzalan, 11th Earl of Arundel]]. However at the behest of King Richard's mother, [[Joan of Kent]], in August 1384 Mortimer's wardship and marriage were granted, for 6000 marks,{{Harvnb|Pugh|1988|p=171}}. to Joan's son, [[Thomas Holland, 2nd Earl of Kent]], and on or about 7 October 1388 Kent married Mortimer to his daughter, Alianore. Roger Mortimer had a claim to the crown through his mother, [[Philippa, 5th Countess of Ulster|Philippa Plantagenet]], daughter of [[Lionel of Antwerp, 1st Duke of Clarence]], and granddaughter of [[Edward III of England|King Edward III]]. Since Richard II had no issue, Roger Mortimer, as his nephew and a lineal descendant of Edward III, was next in line to the throne. Cokayne states that in October 1385 Mortimer was proclaimed by the King as [[heir presumptive]].{{Harvnb|Cokayne|1932|p=448}} This was disputed by Davies who declared that the story that Richard publicly proclaimed Mortimer as heir presumptive in Parliament in October 1385 is baseless, although even Davies admitted the claim was openly discussed at the time.{{Harvnb|Davies|2004}}. The matter was cleared up in 2006 when it was observed that the declaration took place in the parliament of 1386, not that of 1385, and had been dislodged by an interpolation in the Eulogium chronicle, and is supported by a reference in the Westminster Chronicle (see Ian Mortimer, 'Richard II and the Succession to the Crown', ''History'', vol. 91 (2006), pp. 320–36). Alianore and Roger Mortimer had two sons and two daughters:{{Harvnb|Cokayne|1932|p=450}}; {{Harvnb|Richardson III|2011|p=195}} *[[Edmund Mortimer, 5th Earl of March]] *Roger (23 April 1393 – c. 1413){{Harvnb|Pugh|1988|p=61}}; Although some sources state that Roger died c.1409, Pugh states that he was made a Knight of the Bath by Henry V on the eve of his coronation on 9 April 1413. *[[Anne de Mortimer|Anne]], who married [[Richard of Conisburgh, 3rd Earl of Cambridge|Richard, Earl of Cambridge]] (executed 1415) *Eleanor, who married [[Sir Edward de Courtenay]] (d.1418), and had no issue On 20 July 1398, at the age of 24, Roger Mortimer was slain in a skirmish with 'O'Brien's men' at [[Kells, County Meath|Kells]].Davies gives the place name as Kellinstown. The Wigmore chronicler says that he was riding in front of his army, unattended and wearing Irish garb, and that those who slew him did not know who he was. He was interred at [[Wigmore Abbey]].{{Harvnb|Cokayne|1932|p=449}}; {{Harvnb|Richardson III|2011|p=195}} The King went to Ireland in the following year to avenge Mortimer's death.{{Harvnb|Cokayne|1932|p=449}}. The Wigmore chronicler, while criticising Mortimer for lust and remissness in his duty to God, extols him as 'of approved honesty, active in knightly exercises, glorious in pleasantry, affable and merry in conversation, excelling his contemporaries in beauty of appearance, sumptuous in his feasting, and liberal in his gifts'.{{Harvnb|Cokayne|1932|pp=449–50}}. Alianore and Roger Mortimer's young son, [[Edmund Mortimer, 5th Earl of March]], succeeded his father in the title and claim to the throne, and he and his brother, Roger, were kept in custody by King [[Henry IV of England|Henry IV]] until the end of his reign. However Alianore and Roger Mortimer's two daughters, Anne and Eleanor, were in their mother's care until her death in 1405.{{Harvnb|Pugh|1988|pp=77–8}}. According to Griffiths, they were not well treated by the King, and were described as 'destitute' after her death in 1405.{{Harvnb|Griffiths|2004}}. Before 19 June 1399 Alianore married, as her second husband, the 'Welsh marcher lord', [[Edward Charleton, 5th Baron Cherleton]] (1371–1421), by whom she had two daughters:{{Harvnb|Pugh|1988|pp=77–8}}; {{Harvnb|Richardson I|2011|pp=427–8}}. *Joan, who married [[John Grey, 1st Earl of Tankerville]], brother of [[Thomas Grey (1384-1415)|Sir Thomas Grey]], executed for his part in the [[Southampton Plot]] which aimed to replace King [[Henry V of England|Henry V]] with Alianore's son, Edmund Mortimer, 5th Earl of March. Joan and her sister, Joyce, were co-heiresses in 1425 to their stepbrother, Edmund Mortimer, 5th Earl of March. *Joyce, whom married [[John Tiptoft, 1st Baron Tiptoft]]. ==Death== Eleanor died in childbirth in October 1405.{{Harvnb|Cokayne|1932|p=449}}; {{Harvnb|Pugh|1988|p=79}}; {{Harvnb|Richardson I|2011|p=427}}; {{Harvnb|Richardson III|2011|p=195}}; Richardson gives two conflicting dates; on p. 427 he states that Alianore died on 23 October 1405, while on p. 195 he states that she died on 6 or 18 October. She was buried in [[Bisham Abbey|Bisham Priory]], Bisham. Her descendants through her daughter, Anne, include the [[Yorkist]] Kings [[Edward IV of England|Edward IV]] and [[Richard III of England|Richard III]], and [[Anne Bourchier, 7th Baroness Bourchier]]. == Ancestry == {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; | 1 = '''Alianore Holland''' | 2 = [[Thomas Holland, 2nd Earl of Kent]] | 3 = [[Alice FitzAlan (1350-1416)|Alice FitzAlan]] | 4 = [[Thomas Holland, 1st Earl of Kent]] | 5 = [[Joan of Kent]] | 6 = [[Richard Fitzalan, 10th Earl of Arundel]] | 7 = [[Eleanor of Lancaster]] | 8 = [[Robert de Holland, 1st Baron Holand]] | 9 = Maud la Zouche | 10= [[Edmund of Woodstock, 1st Earl of Kent]] | 11= [[Margaret Wake, 3rd Baroness Wake of Liddell]] | 12= [[Edmund Fitzalan, 9th Earl of Arundel]] | 13= [[Alice de Warenne]] | 14= [[Henry, 3rd Earl of Lancaster]] | 15= [[Maud Chaworth]] | 16= Sir Robert de Holland | 17= Elizabeth de Samlesbury | 18= [[Alan la Zouche, 1st Baron la Zouche of Ashby]] | 19= Eleanor de Segrave | 20= [[Edward I of England]] | 21= [[Marguerite of France (born 1282)|Marguerite of France]] | 22= John Wake, 1st Baron Wake of Liddell | 23= Joan de Fiennes | 24= [[Richard Fitzalan, 8th Earl of Arundel]] | 25= [[Alice of Saluzzo]] | 26= William de Warenne | 27= Joan de Vere | 28= [[Edmund Crouchback, 1st Earl of Lancaster]] | 29= [[Blanche of Artois]] | 30= Sir Patrick de Chaworth, Lord of Kidwelly | 31= [[Isabella de Beauchamp]] }} ==Footnotes== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==References== *{{Cite book |title = The Complete Peerage, edited by H.A. In [[embryology]], '''cleavage''' is the division of [[cell (biology)|cell]]s in the early [[embryo]]. The process follows fertilization, with the transfer being triggered by the activation of a [[cyclin-dependent kinase]] complex.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gilbert|first=Scott F.|date=2000|title=An Introduction to Early Developmental Processes|journal=Developmental Biology |edition=6th|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK9992/|language=en}}</ref> The [[zygote]]s of many species undergo rapid [[cell cycle]]s with no significant overall growth, producing a cluster of cells the same size as the original zygote. The different cells derived from cleavage are called [[blastomere]]s and form a compact mass called the [[morula]]. Cleavage ends with the formation of the [[blastula]].
Depending mostly on the amount of [[yolk]] in the egg, the cleavage can be '''holoblastic''' (total or entire cleavage) or '''meroblastic''' (partial cleavage). The pole of the egg with the highest concentration of yolk is referred to as the [[vegetal pole]] while the opposite is referred to as the [[animal pole]].
Cleavage differs from other forms of [[cell division]] in that it increases the number of cells and nuclear mass without increasing the cytoplasmic mass. This means that with each successive subdivision, there is roughly half the cytoplasm in each daughter cell than before that division, and thus the ratio of nuclear to cytoplasmic material increases.<ref>{{cite book|chapter=Cleavage and blastula formation|title=Biological physics of the developing embryo|journal=Biological Physics of the Developing Embryo|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2005|isbn=978-0-521-78337-8|page=27|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rUyVWQhk7CkC&pg=PA27|author1=Forgács, G. |author2=Newman, Stuart A.|bibcode=2005bpde.book.....F|doi=10.2277/0521783372}}</ref>
== Mechanism ==
The rapid cell cycles are facilitated by maintaining high levels of proteins that control cell cycle progression such as the [[cyclin]]s and their associated [[cyclin-dependent kinase]]s (cdk). The complex [[Cyclin B]]/[[CDK1]] a.k.a. MPF ([[maturation promoting factor]]) promotes entry into mitosis.
The processes of [[karyokinesis]] (mitosis) and [[cytokinesis]] work together to result in cleavage. The mitotic apparatus is made up of a [[central spindle]] and polar [[Aster (cell biology)|aster]]s made up of polymers of [[tubulin]] protein called [[microtubules]]. The asters are nucleated by [[centrosomes]] and the centrosomes are organized by centrioles brought into the egg by the sperm as basal bodies. Cytokinesis is mediated by the [[contractile ring]] made up of polymers of [[actin]] protein called [[microfilaments]]. Karyokinesis and cytokinesis are independent but spatially and temporally coordinated processes. While mitosis can occur in the absence of cytokinesis, cytokinesis requires the mitotic apparatus.
The end of cleavage coincides with the beginning of zygotic transcription. This point is referred to as the [[Midblastula|midblastula transition]] and appears to be controlled by the [[NC ratio|nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio]] (about 1/6).
== Types of cleavage ==
=== Determinate ===
Determinate cleavage (also called mosaic cleavage) is in most [[protostome]]s. It results in the developmental fate of the [[Cell (biology)|cells]] being set early in the [[embryo]] [[morphogenesis|development]]. Each blastomere produced by early embryonic cleavage does not have the capacity to develop into a complete [[embryo]].
=== Indeterminate ===
A cell can only be indeterminate (also called regulative) if it has a complete set of undisturbed animal/vegetal cytoarchitectural features. It is characteristic of [[deuterostome]]s – when the original cell in a deuterostome embryo divides, the two resulting cells can be separated, and each one can individually develop into a whole organism.
=== Holoblastic ===
In the absence of a large concentration of yolk, four major cleavage types can be observed in [[isolecithal]] cells (cells with a small even distribution of yolk) or in mesolecithal cells or microlecithal cells (moderate amount of yolk in a gradient) – '''bilateral''' holoblastic, '''radial''' holoblastic, '''rotational''' holoblastic, and '''spiral''' holoblastic, cleavage.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?rid=dbio.section.1767 |title=Early Development of the Nematode Caenorhabditis elegans |journal=Developmental Biology|edition=6th |accessdate=2007-09-17 |format= |year=2000 |last1=Gilbert |first1=Scott F. }}</ref> These holoblastic cleavage planes pass all the way through isolecithal zygotes during the process of cytokinesis. Coeloblastula is the next stage of development for eggs that undergo these radial cleavaging. In holoblastic eggs, the first cleavage always occurs along the vegetal-animal axis of the egg, the second cleavage is perpendicular to the first. From here, the spatial arrangement of blastomeres can follow various patterns, due to different planes of cleavage, in various organisms.
* Bilateral : The first cleavage results in bisection of the zygote into left and right halves. The following cleavage planes are centered on this axis and result in the two halves being mirror images of one another. In bilateral holoblastic cleavage, the divisions of the blastomeres are complete and separate; compared with bilateral meroblastic cleavage, in which the blastomeres stay partially connected.
* Radial : Radial cleavage is characteristic of the [[deuterostomes]], which include some [[vertebrate]]s and [[echinoderm]]s, in which the spindle axes are parallel or at right angles to the polar axis of the [[oocyte]].
* Rotational : Rotational cleavage involves a normal first division along the meridional axis, giving rise to two daughter cells. The way in which this cleavage differs is that one of the daughter cells divides meridionally, whilst the other divides equatorially.
: [[Mammal]]s display rotational cleavage, and an [[isolecithal]] distribution of yolk (sparsely and evenly distributed). Because the cells have only a small amount of yolk, they require immediate implantation onto the uterine wall in order to receive nutrients.
: The [[nematode]] [[Caenorhabditis elegans|''C. elegans'']], a popular developmental model organism, undergoes holoblastic rotational cell cleavage.<ref>{{cite book | title=Developmental biology| edition=11th| author=Gilbert SF| year=2016| pages=268| publisher=Sinauer| isbn=9781605354705}}</ref> * Spiral : Spiral cleavage is conserved between many members of the [[lophotrochozoa]]n taxa, referred to as [[Spiralia]].<ref name=Shankland>{{cite journal |pmid=10781038 |pmc=34316 |jstor=122407 |bibcode=2000PNAS...97.4434S |doi=10.1073/pnas.97.9.4434|title = Evolution of the bilaterian body plan: What have we learned from annelids?|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |volume=97 |issue=9 |pages=4434–7 |year = 2000|last1 = Shankland|first1 = M.|last2=Seaver |first2=E. C. }}</ref> Most spiralians undergo equal spiral cleavage, although some undergo unequal cleavage (see below).<ref name="Henry2002">{{Cite journal | last1 = Henry | first1 = J. | title = Conserved Mechanism of Dorsoventral Axis Determination in Equal-Cleaving Spiralians | journal = Developmental Biology | volume = 248 | issue = 2 | pages = 343–355 | year = 2002 | pmid = 12167409 | doi = 10.1006/dbio.2002.0741}}</ref> This group includes [[annelid]]s, [[mollusc]]s, and [[sipuncula]]. Spiral cleavage can vary between species, but generally the first two cell divisions result in four macromeres, also called blastomeres, (A, B, C, D) each representing one quadrant of the embryo. These first two cleavages are not oriented in planes that occur at right angles parallel to the animal-vegetal axis of the [[zygote]].<ref name= Shankland/> At the 4-cell stage, the A and C macromeres meet at the animal pole, creating the animal cross-furrow, while the B and D macromeres meet at the vegetal pole, creating the vegetal cross-furrow.<ref name=Boyer>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/icb/38.4.621 |jstor=4620189 |title=Evolutionary Modifications of the Spiralian Developmental Program |journal=Integrative and Comparative Biology |volume=38 |issue=4 |pages=621–33 |year=1998 |last1=Boyer |first1=Barbara C. |last2=Jonathan |first2=Q. Henry}}</ref> With each successive cleavage cycle, the macromeres give rise to quartets of smaller micromeres at the animal pole.<ref name=Freeman>{{cite journal |doi=10.1046/j.1420-9101.1992.5020205.x |title=Evolutionary implications of the mode of D quadrant specification in coelomates with spiral cleavage |journal=Journal of Evolutionary Biology |volume=5 |issue=2 |pages=205–47 |year=1992 |last1=Freeman |first1=Gary |last2=Lundelius |first2=Judith W.}}</ref><ref name=Lambert>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.ydbio.2003.07.006 |pmid=14597198 |title=The MAPK cascade in equally cleaving spiralian embryos |journal=Developmental Biology |volume=263 |issue=2 |pages=231–41 |year=2003 |last1=Lambert |first1=J.David |last2=Nagy |first2=Lisa M}}</ref> The divisions that produce these quartets occur at an oblique angle, an angle that is not a multiple of 90°, to the animal-vegetal axis.<ref name= Lambert/> Each quartet of micromeres is rotated relative to their parent macromere, and the chirality of this rotation differs between odd and even numbered quartets, meaning that there is alternating symmetry between the odd and even quartets.<ref name= Shankland/> In other words, the orientation of divisions that produces each quartet alternates between being clockwise and counterclockwise with respect to the animal pole.<ref name= Lambert/> The alternating cleavage pattern that occurs as the quartets are generated produces quartets of micromeres that reside in the cleavage furrows of the four macromeres.<ref name= Boyer/> When viewed from the animal pole, this arrangement of cells displays a spiral pattern.
[[File:equal vs unequal cleavage.jpg|thumb|D quadrant specification through equal and unequal cleavage mechanisms. At the 4-cell stage of equal cleavage, the D macromere has not been specified yet. It will be specified after the formation of the third quartet of micromeres. Unequal cleavage occurs in two ways: asymmetric positioning of the mitotic spindle, or through the formation of a polar lobe (PL).]]
: Specification of the D macromere and is an important aspect of spiralian development. Although the primary axis, animal-vegetal, is determined during [[oogenesis]], the secondary axis, dorsal-ventral, is determined by the specification of the D quadrant.<ref name= Lambert/> The D macromere facilitates cell divisions that differ from those produced by the other three macromeres. Cells of the D quadrant give rise to dorsal and posterior structures of the spiralian.<ref name= Lambert/> Two known mechanisms exist to specify the D quadrant. These mechanisms include equal cleavage and unequal cleavage.
: In equal cleavage, the first two cell divisions produce four macromeres that are indistinguishable from one another. Each macromere has the potential of becoming the D macromere.<ref name= Freeman/> After the formation of the third quartet, one of the macromeres initiates maximum contact with the overlying micromeres in the animal pole of the embryo.<ref name= Freeman/><ref name= Lambert/> This contact is required to distinguish one macromere as the official D quadrant blastomere. In equally cleaving spiral embryos, the D quadrant is not specified until after the formation of the third quartet, when contact with the micromeres dictates one cell to become the future D blastomere. Once specified, the D blastomere signals to surrounding micromeres to lay out their cell fates.<ref name= Lambert/>
: In unequal cleavage, the first two cell divisions are unequal producing four cells in which one cell is bigger than the other three. This larger cell is specified as the D macromere.<ref name= Freeman/><ref name= Lambert/> Unlike equally cleaving spiralians, the D macromere is specified at the four-cell stage during unequal cleavage. Unequal cleavage can occur in two ways. One method involves asymmetric positioning of the cleavage spindle.<ref name= Lambert/> This occurs when the [[aster (cell biology)|aster]] at one pole attaches to the cell membrane, causing it to be much smaller than the aster at the other pole.<ref name= Freeman/> This results in an unequal [[cytokinesis]], in which both macromeres inherit part of the animal region of the egg, but only the bigger macromere inherits the vegetal region.<ref name= Freeman/> The second mechanism of unequal cleavage involves the production of an enucleate, membrane bound, cytoplasmic protrusion, called a polar lobe.<ref name= Freeman/> This polar lobe forms at the vegetal pole during cleavage, and then gets shunted to the D blastomere.<ref name= Boyer/><ref name= Freeman/> The polar lobe contains vegetal cytoplasm, which becomes inherited by the future D macromere.<ref name= Lambert/>
[[File:Spiral cleavage in Trochus.png|center|600px|thumb|Spiral cleavage in marine snail of the genus ''[[Trochus]]''.]]
=== Meroblastic ===
In the presence of a large amount of yolk in the fertilized egg cell, the cell can undergo partial, or meroblastic, cleavage. Two major types of meroblastic cleavage are '''discoidal''' and '''superficial'''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ucalgary.ca/UofC/eduweb/virtualembryo/currentnotes.html |title=Current Notes |accessdate=2007-09-17 |website=}}{{unreliable source?|date=April 2014}}</ref>
* Discoidal : In discoidal cleavage, the cleavage furrows do not penetrate the yolk. The embryo forms a disc of cells, called a blastodisc, on top of the yolk. Discoidal cleavage is commonly found in [[monotremes]], [[birds]], [[reptiles]], and [[fish]] that have [[telolecithal]] egg cells (egg cells with the yolk concentrated at one end). The layer of cells that have incompletely divided and are in contact with the yolk are called the "syncytial layer".
* Superficial : In superficial cleavage, [[mitosis]] occurs but not [[cytokinesis]], resulting in a polynuclear cell. With the yolk positioned in the center of the egg cell, the nuclei migrate to the periphery of the egg, and the plasma membrane grows inward, partitioning the nuclei into individual cells. Superficial cleavage occurs in [[arthropods]] that have [[centrolecithal]] egg cells (egg cells with the yolk located in the center of the cell). This type of cleavage can work to promote synchronicity in developmental timing, such as in ''Drosophila''.<ref name=Gilbert>Gilbert SF. Developmental Biology 11th edition. Sunderland (MA): Sinauer Associates; 2014. Print</ref>
{| align="center" class="toccolours" border="1" style="border:1px solid gray; border-collapse:collapse;" |+ '''Summary of the main patterns of cleavage and [[vitellogenesis|yolk accumulation]] (after <ref>{{cite book | title=Developmental biology| edition=7th| author=Gilbert SF| year=2003| pages=214| publisher=Sinauer| isbn=978-0-87893-258-0}}</ref> and <ref>{{cite book |title=Vertebrates: Comparative Anatomy, Function, Evolution |edition=4th |last1=Kardong |first1=Kenneth V. |year=2006 |pages=158–64 |publisher=McGraw-Hill}}</ref>). |- !I. Holoblastic (complete) cleavage !II. Meroblastic (incomplete) cleavage |- valign="top" | A. Isolecithal (sparse, evenly distributed yolk)
* 1. Radial cleavage ([[echinoderms]], [[hemichordate]]s, [[amphioxus]]) * 2. Spiral cleavage ([[annelid]]s, most [[mollusk]]s, [[flatworms]]) * 3. Bilateral cleavage ([[tunicate]]s) * 4. Rotational cleavage ([[placental mammal]]s, [[nematode]]s, [[marsupial]]s [?])
B. Mesolecithal (moderate vegetal yolk disposition)
* Displaced radial cleavage ([[amphibian]]s, some fish [the [[lamprey]]s, [[gar]]s and [[bowfin]]s)
| A. Telolecithal (dense yolk throughout most of cell)
* 1. Bilateral cleavage ([[Cephalopoda|cephalopod molluscs]]) * 2. Discoidal cleavage (some [[fish]] [the [[hagfish]]es, [[chondrichthyan]]s and most [[teleost]]s], [[Sauropsida|sauropsids]] [reptiles and birds], [[monotreme]]s)
B. Centrolecithal (yolk in center of egg)
* Superficial cleavage (most [[insect]]s)
|- valign="top" |}
== Placentals ==
[[File:HumanEmbryogenesis.svg|thumb|300px|The initial stages of [[human embryogenesis]].]]
Differences exist between the cleavage in [[placentalia|placental mammals]] and the cleavage in other animals. Mammals have a slow rate of division that is between 12 and 24 hours. These cellular divisions are asynchronous. Zygotic transcription starts at the two-, four-, or eight-cell stage. Cleavage is holoblastic and rotational.
At the eight-cell stage, having undergone three cleavages the embryo goes through some changes. At this stage the cells begin to tightly [[cell adhesion|adhere]] in a process known as compaction.<ref name="Nikas">{{cite journal |last1=Nikas |first1=G |last2=Ao |first2=A |last3=Winston |first3=RM |last4=Handyside |first4=AH |title=Compaction and surface polarity in the human embryo in vitro. |journal=Biology of Reproduction |date=July 1996 |volume=55 |issue=1 |pages=32–7 |pmid=8793055}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Nikas G, Ao A, Winston RM, Handyside AH |title=Compaction and surface polarity in the human embryo in vitro |journal=Biol. Reprod. |volume=55 |issue=1 |pages=32–7 |date=July 1996 |pmid=8793055 |doi= 10.1095/biolreprod55.1.32|url=http://www.biolreprod.org/cgi/reprint/55/1/32.pdf|format=pdf}}</ref> A single cell can be removed from a pre-compaction eight- cell embryo and used for [[genetic testing]].<ref name="Wilton">{{cite journal |last1=Wilton |first1=L |title=Preimplantation genetic diagnosis and chromosome analysis of blastomeres using comparative genomic hybridization. |journal=Human Reproduction Update |date=NaN |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=33–41 |doi=10.1093/humupd/dmh050 |pmid=15569702}}</ref>
Most of the blastomeres in this stage become polarized and develop tight junctions with the other blastomeres. This process leads to the development of two different populations of cells: Polar cells on the outside and apolar cells on the inside. The outer cells, called the [[trophoblast]] cells, pump sodium in from the outside, which automatically brings water in with it to the basal (inner) surface to form a blastocoel cavity in a process called compaction. The trophoblast cells will eventually give rise to the embryonic contribution to the placenta called the [[chorion]]. The inner cells are pushed to one side of the cavity (because the embryo isn't getting any bigger) to form the [[inner cell mass]] (ICM) and will give rise to the embryo and some [[extraembryonic membrane]]s. At this stage, the embryo is called a [[blastocyst]].
