{{Use Irish English|date=April 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox police officer |name = Adrian Donohoe |image= File:Lordship Credit Union, Lordship, Co. Louth - geograph.org.uk - 355595.jpg |caption= Lorship Credit Union, the site where the attack occurred. |birth_date = 14 January 1972 |death_date = 25 January 2013 (aged 41) |birth_place = [[Kilnaleck]], [[County Cavan]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] |death_place = Bellurgan, [[County Louth]], Ireland |department = [[Garda Síochána]] |rank = [[Detective]] Garda |badgenumber = 26222F |serviceyears = 1994–2013 (19 years) }} Detective Garda '''Adrian Donohoe''' (14 January 1972 – 25 January 2013) was an Irish police [[detective]] working for the [[Garda Síochána]], the national police service of [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]. He was attached to [[Dundalk]] Garda Station in [[County Louth]], and was fatally shot in Bellurgan, County Louth (near [[Jenkinstown, County Louth|Jenkinstown]]) on 25 January 2013 by an armed gang of five people during a robbery on a [[credit union]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Detective Garda killed in Co Louth shooting|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2013/0125/364600-garda-louth-shot/|work=25 January 2013|publisher=RTÉ News|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref> He was the first garda officer to be shot dead in the line of duty since 1996, and was afforded a full [[state funeral]].
On 4 March 2018, 27-year-old Aaron Brady from New Road, Crossmaglen, County Armagh, was charged with the capital murder of a member of the Garda Síochána in the course of their duty before Dundalk District Court.<ref>{{cite news|title=Adrian Donohoe: Crossmaglen man charged with murder|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43279863|accessdate=5 March 2018|publisher=BBC News|date=4 March 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Adrian Donohoe was born on 14 January 1972 in [[Kilnaleck|Kilnaleck, County Cavan]] to parents Peggy and Hugh Donohoe. He grew up on the family farm with his three brothers - Alan, Colm and Martin, and two sisters - Anne and Mary. He was a keen [[Gaelic football]]er, and at {{convert|6|ft|4|in|m|2|abbr=on}} he played midfield for his local club before going on to represent [[Cavan GAA]] at Under-21 level.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lally|first=Conor|title=State funeral of murdered Garda held in Co Louth|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2013/0130/breaking2.html|accessdate=18 February 2013|newspaper=Irish Times|date=30 January 2013}}</ref> He attended nearby primary and secondary schools, before joining the Garda Síochána in 1994. Two of his brothers also joined the force, and he met his future wife Caroline at the [[Garda Síochána College]] in [[Templemore]], [[County Tipperary]].
Caroline Donohoe, from [[County Clare]] and who also had family members serving with the Gardaí, was stationed with the [[Garda National Immigration Bureau]] (GNIB) in Dundalk Garda Station - the same building where her husband worked – and the couple had two young children, a boy and a girl aged 6 and 7 respectively, at the time of his death.<ref>{{cite news|title=Murdered garda dedicated his life to GAA, the Guards and his family |url=http://www.sundayworld.com/columnists/index.php?aid=14341 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130411223957/http://www.sundayworld.com/columnists/index.php?aid=14341 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=11 April 2013 |accessdate=18 February 2013 |newspaper=Sunday World |date=27 January 2013 }}</ref> Donohoe was described as a "father figure" in his community, and played and coached for his local GAA club, St Patrick’s GFC, on the [[Cooley Peninsula]]. He served his entire 19-year career in Dundalk, rising to the rank of detective. The Donohoes lived 4 km away from where the shooting occurred, and both their children attended Bellurgan National School, directly across the road from the incident.
==Shooting and robbery== Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe and his colleague Detective Garda Joe Ryan were on a routine two-person [[Cash-in-transit|cash escort]] on the evening of Friday, 25 January 2013. Ryan was driving an [[unmarked police car]] (a silver [[Ford Mondeo]]), both detectives were wearing civilian clothing and carrying concealed police issue sidearms (9mm [[SIG Sauer P226]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=Adrian Donohoe was diligent, popular officer: Commissioner Callinan|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/adrian-donohoe-was-diligent-popular-officer-commissioner-callinan-582621.html|work=26 January 2013|publisher=BreakingNews.ie|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref> The Garda Síochána are primarily an unarmed police force, however certain units of the service are armed (such as detective units) and up to 25% of members are licensed to carry firearms. The pair were en route to meet local credit union officials at [[Omeath]], Cooley and the Lordship Credit Union in Bellurgan, who would then travel in a three car convoy to a bank in Dundalk town to lodge takings in a nightsafe. This was regular practice, and the protocol had been recently upgraded from an unarmed, uniformed garda escort to an armed, plain-clothes detective escort following a robbery that happened at the credit union 18 months prior, when €62,000 in cash and cheques was taken. There were no casualties in the previous crime.<ref>{{cite news|title=Taoiseach condemns killing of garda as manhunt continues|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/taoiseach-condemns-killing-of-garda-as-manhunt-continues-29023106.html|accessdate=18 February 2013|newspaper=Irish Independent|date=26 January 2013}}</ref>
At 9:30 pm, Donohoe and Ryan entered the car park of the Lordship Credit Union premises and they parked, as did another car that was accompanying them from another credit union branch. They both parked beside the car belonging to officials from Lordship. At this point a navy-blue coloured [[Volkswagen Passat]] - that had been waiting stationary on the [[hard shoulder]] of the road - drove across the road and blocked the entrance. Four members of the gang were hiding behind a wall surrounding the car park, all wearing [[Balaclava (clothing)|balaclavas]], while a fifth was driving the car. Two gang members approached the detectives' car from the rear, and as Donohoe opened his door and stepped out to investigate why the car had blocked the entrance, he was instantly shot at close range in the back of the head with a [[shotgun|long barrelled shotgun]] by a masked raider. A single shot was fired.<ref>{{cite news|last=Murphy|first=Hubert|title=Second brutal slaying of a garda in Louth|url=http://www.independent.ie/regionals/droghedaindependent/news/second-brutal-slaying-of-a-garda-in-louth-29029766.html|accessdate=18 February 2013|newspaper=Drogheda Independent|date=30 January 2013}}</ref> It was dark, and before Ryan could realise what was taking place he was held at gunpoint and ordered out of his car and onto the ground by a number of gang members possessing a shotgun, handgun and a hammer. Neither officer had time to draw their weapons. The raiders then broke into a car belonging to credit union staff from Lordship, threatening them, which was carrying cash and cheques to the value of about €40,000, but only took a bag with €4,000, mistakenly leaving behind more than €30,000.<ref>{{cite web|title=Det Garda Adrian Donohoe to be laid to rest on Wednesday|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/funeral-garda-adrian-donohoe-771793-Jan2013/|work=28 January 2013|publisher=TheJournal.ie|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref> Ryan and the credit union staff were left physically uninjured as the gang of five fled the scene, but Ryan was dispossessed of his car keys in an attempt to hinder his reaction. It was only after the perpetrators had escaped that the alarm could be raised.
The emergency services pronounced Donohoe dead shortly after their arrival, despite the frantic efforts of his colleague Ryan to save his life.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gardaí probing death of Adrian Donohoe make new appeal|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/adrian-donohoe-was-diligent-popular-officer-commissioner-callinan-582621.html|accessdate=18 February 2013|newspaper=Irish Examiner|date=26 January 2013}}</ref> Garda Headquarters scrambled all available units in an attempt to catch the fleeing suspects, and alerted the [[Police Service of Northern Ireland]] (PSNI). However, it is understood they had escaped to [[Northern Ireland]] before the [[Republic of Ireland–United Kingdom border|border]] was secured by police on both sides.<ref>{{cite web|last=Garda Press Office|title=Update on Fatal Shooting of Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe|url=http://www.garda.ie/Controller.aspx?Page=10667|work=28 January 2013|publisher=Garda Síochána na hÉireann|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref> The Republic of Ireland-United Kingdom border can be crossed by car in around 10 minutes from the Lordship Credit Union, and neither force is allowed to enter neighbouring territory. A [[Garda Air Support Unit|Garda helicopter]] briefly entered UK airspace with permission during the search. A PSNI helicopter was also deployed during the search in the north.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hutton |first=Brian |title=Tributes to slain garda at state funeral |url=http://www.irishecho.com.au/tag/detective-garda-adrian-donohoe |accessdate=18 February 2013 |newspaper=Irish Echo |date=31 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104164945/http://www.irishecho.com.au/tag/detective-garda-adrian-donohoe |archivedate= 4 November 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==Investigation== One hour after the fatal incident - at 10:30 pm on Friday, 25 January 2013 - a car matching the description of that used in the credit union hold-up was found burnt-out on Cumsons Road, Newtownhamilton, a remote forested laneway near the villages of [[Darkley]] and [[Keady]], in south [[County Armagh]] in Northern Ireland. The PSNI carried out an extensive technical examination of the car and the surrounding area the following day. This area became a focus of the investigation. The vehicle, a "graphite navy blue" in colour 2008 [[Dublin]] registered [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] [[Volkswagen Passat]], was linked by detectives to the murder and it was confirmed that it had been stolen from the [[Clogherhead]] area of County Louth earlier that week, between 11:30 pm on Tuesday, 22 January and 4:30 am on Wednesday, 23 January.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fresh appeal over murder of Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21395708|work=9 February 2013|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref> Gardaí and the PSNI believe another getaway car was used to collected those involved in the crime after setting alight the original getaway car, and that there was more than five suspects involved in the overall perpetration of the crime.
A full [[forensic examination]] was carried out at the scene over three days by the [[Garda Technical Bureau]], assisted by the Divisional Scenes of Crime Unit. The Divisional Search Team was called in to search the vicinity of the scene. The hammer used by the raiders to break the window of one of the credit union cars was recovered at the crime scene.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tributes paid to Garda detective |url=http://www.tv3.ie/article.php?article_id=93918 |work=26 January 2013 |publisher=TV3 News |accessdate=18 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201100429/http://www.tv3.ie/article.php?article_id=93918 |archivedate= 1 February 2014 |df= }}</ref>
The post-mortem on the body of Donohoe took place at [[Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital (Drogheda)|Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital]] in Drogheda by the State Pathologist, Professor [[Marie Cassidy]] of the [[State Pathologist's Office]], who also visited the scene.<ref>{{cite news|title=Murdered Irish policeman's partner threatened as he ran to help dying detective after botched robbery|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2268932/Adrian-Donohue-Murdered-Irish-policemans-partner-threatened-ran-help-dying-detective.html|accessdate=18 February 2013|newspaper=The Daily Mail|date=27 January 2013|author=Debbie McCann|author2=Alison O'Reilly}}</ref>
As is standard practice when a garda loses their life, the [[Garda Síochána Ombudsman Commission]] (GSOC) was notified, and their officials visited the scene.
Then Garda [[Police commissioner|Commissioner]] [[Martin Callinan]] (who retired in March 2014) attended a case conference at Dundalk Garda Station on the weekend after Donohoe's death, where an incident room was established for the duration of the investigation. Commissioner Callinan announced the allocation of 150 senior detectives to the case. The investigation team would be led by Assistant Commissioner Kieran Kenny of the Northern Region, Chief Superintendent Pat McGee of the County Louth Division, Superintendent Gerry Curley and Detective Superintendent John O'Reilly of Dundalk Garda Station.<ref>{{cite news|title=We know Adrian Donohoe's killers|url=http://www.thesun.ie/irishsol/homepage/news/4786284/We-know-Adrian-Donohoes-killers.html|accessdate=18 February 2013|newspaper=The Irish Sun|date=9 February 2013}}</ref> National specialist units were assigned to the investigation, including the [[Special Detective Unit]] (SDU), [[National Bureau of Criminal Investigation]] (NBCI) and [[Organised Crime Unit]] (OCU). The force's armed intervention teams - [[Garda Emergency Response Unit|Emergency Response Unit]] (ERU) and [[Regional Support Unit]] (RSU) - were placed on alert in the aftermath.<ref>{{cite web|title=Possibility That Murdered Detective Knew His Killer |url=http://www.citizensfreepressireland.com/2013_02_01_archive.html |work=1 February 2013 |publisher=Citizen's Free Press Ireland |accessdate=18 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208105734/http://www.citizensfreepressireland.com/2013_02_01_archive.html |archivedate= 8 February 2013 |df= }}</ref>
In the early stages of the investigation, there were over 1,000 Garda officers attached to the investigation, making it one of the largest criminal investigations ever undertaken in the history of the state.<ref>{{cite news|last1=O’Doherty|first1=Caroline|title=Community ‘still hurting’ over Adrian’s death|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/viewpoints/analysis/community-still-hurting-over-adrians-death-308708.html|accessdate=24 January 2015|publisher=The Irish Examiner|date=24 January 2015}}</ref>
Gardaí established that five males were involved in the shooting and robbery itself, and belong to a larger criminal gang operating in the border region.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gardaí probing death of Adrian Donohoe make new appeal |url=http://www.kildare-nationalist.ie/2013/02/08/gardai-probing-death-of-adrian-donohoe-make-new-appeal/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130412225048/http://www.kildare-nationalist.ie/2013/02/08/gardai-probing-death-of-adrian-donohoe-make-new-appeal/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 April 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2013 |newspaper=Kildare Nationalist |date=8 February 2013 }}</ref> Those responsible were believed to have fled to Northern Ireland after the killing, and remained there for some weeks. The leader of the five-man gang and main suspect for the murder was identified as a young man from the [[Crossmaglen]] area of south Armagh. It is understood he was known to Detective Donohoe, providing a possible [[Motive (law)|motive]] for his murder. However, Donohoe was originally not scheduled to take part in the credit union cash escort, making a late shift change with the officer who was originally scheduled to take part in the escort.<ref>{{cite news|last=Cusack|first=Jim|title=Detectives know gunman's identity but extradition may pose problem|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/garda-hunt-for-adrians-killers-being-wound-down-29090533.html|accessdate=24 February 2013|newspaper=Independent|date=24 February 2013}}</ref>
In late February, over a month after Donohoe died, Gardaí held a press briefing at the [[Dublin Metropolitan Area#Garda usage|Dublin Metropolitan Region]] (DMR) Headquarters in [[Harcourt Street]], Dublin City. There was a renewed appeal for information made, and two replica exhibits of evidence were shown to the media for the first time. A precision [[mallet|panel beating hammer]] with a black rubber handle, a red painted section and a soft rubber head was found at the scene, and police asked the public for help in tracing its origins. Similar mallets are used by [[panel beater]]s or mechanics repairing motorcycles. Also, a distinctive green "Cosatto" high-backed [[Child safety seat|children's car booster seat]] carrying a "Little Monster" motif as well as a graphic of a monster was in the car when it was stolen. The child car seat - suitable for babies and young children - cost €119 to buy, and may have been dumped, offered for sale or given as a gift as investigators believe was taken out of the stolen vehicle before it was used in the killing.<ref>{{cite web|title=Renewed Appeal For Information on Garda Killing |url=http://www.98fm.com/2013/category-news-sport/renewed-appeal-for-information-on-garda-killing/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130410041501/http://www.98fm.com/2013/category-news-sport/renewed-appeal-for-information-on-garda-killing/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=10 April 2013 |work=26 February 2013 |publisher=98 FM Radio |accessdate=26 February 2013 }}</ref>
In mid-April, Gardaí and the PSNI informed the public that the investigation teams were looking for information in relation to a white coloured [[Heavy Goods Vehicle]] (HGV) that was parked on the Shean Road, [[Forkhill]], Armagh in Northern Ireland either side of 9.45 pm on 25 January 2013, the night Donohoe lost his life. The white lorry may have been broken down, and a number of people were reportedly seen around the vehicle. The two police forces added that they wanted to speak to anyone who owned the truck, had recovered or serviced it, or anyone who saw any activity of this nature on the Shean Road on the night of 25 January.<ref>{{cite news|title=Child seat clue in murder inquiry|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/child-seat-clue-in-murder-inquiry-29096245.html|accessdate=26 February 2013|newspaper=Irish Independent|date=26 February 2013}}</ref>
One year on from the murder of Detective Donohoe, the Garda Commissioner visited Dundalk Garda Station, and provided an update on the progress of the murder inquiry. Martin Callinan reiterated his commitment to bringing those responsible for the crime to justice, and revealed the international dimensions to the case, involving police forces and law enforcement agencies from the [[United Kingdom]], [[Netherlands]], [[United States]] and [[Australia]], as well as [[Europol]] and [[Interpol]]. The Commissioner also praised the PSNI for their involvement in the investigation. By the 25 January 2014, the anniversary of Donohoe's death, over 4,000 investigative tasks had been undertaken, 4,000 "structured" lines of enquiry lines were pursued, 2,100 statements taken, in excess of 800 people interviewed, 400,000 hours of CCTV reviewed (the equivalent to 45 [[man year|man-years]]), 1,200 exhibits of evidence gathered and more than 30 searches carried out under warrants during the 12 months of the investigation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Garda statement on anniversary of murder of Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe|url=http://static.rasset.ie/documents/news/garda-statement-on-anniversary-of-murder-of-detective-garda-adrian-donohoe.pdf|work=24 January 2014|publisher=An Garda Síochána|accessdate=25 January 2014}}</ref>
Succeeding Garda Commissioner [[Nóirín O'Sullivan]] reiterated her confidence in April 2014 that Adrian Donohoe's murderers would be brought to justice.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McMahon|first1=Cathal|title="We'll bring Adrian's killers to justice"|url=http://www.irishmirror.ie/news/irish-news/crime/irelands-top-cop-noirin-osullivan-3475591|accessdate=24 June 2014|publisher=Irish Mirror|date=30 April 2014}}</ref> The investigation into the murder is over 10 times the size of usual homicide investigations.<ref name="adrian donohoe 1">{{cite news|last1=Neilan|first1=Paul|title=Three Donohoe murder suspects still in US|url=http://www.anglocelt.ie/news/roundup/articles/2014/06/20/4031069-three-donohoe-murder-suspects-still-in-us/|accessdate=24 June 2014|publisher=The Anglo Celt|date=20 June 2014}}</ref>
==Aftermath== The death of Adrian Donohoe was strongly condemned by the [[President of Ireland]], [[Michael D. Higgins]] and the [[Taoiseach]], [[Enda Kenny]]. Cabinet ministers in the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland also spoke out against the crime. [[Minister for Justice and Equality|Minister for Justice]] [[Alan Shatter]] said that those responsible for the murder had planned it, knew that there would be police attending the credit union for an escort, and that the officers were [[ambush]]ed. He warned that the perpetrators would each face the mandatory 40 years in prison for killing a garda, regardless of who fired the shot if they did not turn themselves in. Commissioner Martin Callinan vowed to hunt down and apprehend the killers. The PSNI, under Chief Constable [[Matt Baggott]], pledged their full cooperation and support to bring to justice the murderers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Adrian Donohoe Killing Condemned By Irish PM|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1043114/adrian-donohoe-killing-condemned-by-irish-pm|work=26 January 2013|publisher=Sky News|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref>
There was widespread shock and outrage among the public on the island of Ireland following the shooting dead of Donohoe, and it was considered a "national tragedy". The [[Death of Jerry McCabe|last garda to be shot dead serving the state]] was Detective Garda Jerry McCabe in June 1996, by the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] (IRA) in [[County Limerick]]. Jerry McCabe's widow Anne McCabe spoke of her sympathy for the Donohoe family, and retired Detective Garda Ben O'Sullivan - who was shot but survived the same incident as Jerry McCabe - signed a book of condolence for the family, friends and colleagues of the fallen officer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jerry McCabe's widow calls for tough sentences for garda killers|url=http://www.newstalk.ie/Jerry-McCabes-widow-calls-for-tough-sentences-for-garda-killers|work=28 January 2013|publisher=Newstalk Radio|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref>
Irish television programme ''[[Crimecall]]'' aired on [[RTÉ Television|RTÉ]] in February, featuring Superintendent David Taylor from the Garda Press Office appealing to the public for their help in solving the case.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fresh calls for information over Garda murder |url=http://insideireland.ie/2013/02/18/fresh-calls-for-information-over-garda-murder-86714/ |work=18 February 2013 |publisher=Inside Ireland Website |accessdate=18 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130308055033/http://insideireland.ie/2013/02/18/fresh-calls-for-information-over-garda-murder-86714/ |archivedate= 8 March 2013 |df= }}</ref> A [[Facebook]] tribute to Donohoe amassed over 40,000 signatures within days of the killing. The [[Irish League of Credit Unions]] offered a reward of €50,000 for information leading to arrests and prosecutions in the investigation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Credit Unions offer €50,000 reward for information on Garda murder|url=http://www.joe.ie/news-politics/current-affairs/credit-unions-offer-e50000-reward-for-information-on-garda-murder-0033456-1|work=30 January 2013|publisher=Joe.ie|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref> This reward was added to by [[Crimestoppers]], who put forward a "substantial, five-figure sum" a month after the incident.<ref>{{cite news|title=We’re still hunting garda killers |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/republic-of-ireland/were-still-hunting-garda-killers-29092157.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130420081213/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/republic-of-ireland/were-still-hunting-garda-killers-29092157.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=20 April 2013 |accessdate=25 February 2013 |newspaper=Belfast Telegraph |date=25 February 2013 }}</ref>
On 18 May 2013, the family of Adrian Donohoe were presented with a special Garda remembrance medal in his honour. The medal was awarded to his widow, Caroline, during the annual Garda Memorial Day commemoration service held at [[Dublin Castle]]. The ceremony remembers all 87 members of the Gardaí who were killed in the line of duty.<ref>{{cite web|title=Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe's family receive medal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22580068|work=19 May 2013|publisher=BBC News NI|accessdate=24 May 2013}}</ref>
Donohoe was posthumously awarded a [[People of the Year Award]] for his bravery and fearlessness in September 2013, eight months after his unlawful death. The award was presented in [[Citywest]], Dublin by [[Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA]] personality [[Mícheál Ó Muircheartaigh]], and was accepted by Caroline Donohoe. She spoke of Adrian as "the love of my life" and "the best father that any child could have", adding "I will miss him every minute of every day as long as I live".<ref>{{cite web|title=‘I will miss him every minute of every day’|url=http://www.dundalkdemocrat.ie/news/local-news/i-will-miss-him-every-minute-of-every-day-1-5498563|work=17 September 2013|publisher=The Dundalk Democrat Newspaper|accessdate=24 September 2013}}</ref>
==Funeral== Detective Garda Donohoe was given a full [[List of Irish state funerals|state funeral]] on 30 January 2013. The funeral mass took place at St Joseph's Redemptorist Church in Dundalk, and he was buried at Lordship Cemetery. There was an estimated 5,000 people present at the funeral, which included 3,500 Gardaí (2,500 uniformed and 1,000 plain-clothes) and 1,500 members of the locality and further afield. More lined the route as the procession made its way to the graveyard. It was the largest funeral in Ireland for a number of years. Among those in attendance were President Michael D. Higgins, Taoiseach Enda Kenny, [[Tánaiste]] [[Eamon Gilmore]], Minister for Justice Alan Shatter and several senior government ministers, Garda Commissioner Martin Callinan, [[Irish Defence Forces]] [[Chief of Staff of the Defence Forces (Ireland)|Chief of Staff]] Lieutenant General [[Sean McCann (soldier)|Sean McCann]], Cardinal [[Seán Brady]], [[Secretary of State for Northern Ireland|Northern Ireland Secretary of State]] [[Theresa Villiers]], Northern Ireland Justice Minister [[David Ford]] and PSNI Chief Constable Matt Baggott. Fr Michael Cusack presided over the mass. Donohoe's colleague Joe Ryan, who was present when he was shot dead, was a [[pall-bearer]] at the funeral.<ref>{{cite news|last=O'Toole|first=Michael|title=Thousands turn out for funeral of slain garda Adrian Donohoe|url=http://www.thestar.ie/star/thousands-turn-out-for-funeral-of-slain-garda-adrian-donohoe/|accessdate=18 February 2013|newspaper=Irish Daily Star|date=31 January 2013|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130412231229/http://www.thestar.ie/star/thousands-turn-out-for-funeral-of-slain-garda-adrian-donohoe/#|archive-date=12 April 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Police inquiries== In late February 2013, six pre-planned searches were carried out in the Dundalk area by Gardaí investigating the murder. Two men - a father and son in their 70s and 30s - were detained under terrorism legislation ([[Offences against the State Acts 1939–1998]]) and held at [[Drogheda]] Garda Station, where they could be detained for a period of 7 days without charge.<ref>{{cite news|last=Foy|first=Ken|title=Hammer is found at scene where Garda Donohoe murdered|url=http://www.herald.ie/news/hammer-is-found-at-scene-where-garda-donohoe-murdered-29095713.html|accessdate=26 February 2013|newspaper=Herald|date=26 February 2013}}</ref> A Garda spokesperson said that the arrests targeted criminal and subversive activity in the area, and were not directly related to the killing.<ref>{{cite web|title=Two arrests in Co Louth over criminality |url=http://www.u.tv/News/Two-arrests-in-Co-Louth-over-criminality/9c776e9f-c286-44a1-bceb-21a4a04665e2 |work=21 February 2013 |publisher=UTV News |accessdate=21 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103234748/http://www.u.tv/News/Two-arrests-in-Co-Louth-over-criminality/9c776e9f-c286-44a1-bceb-21a4a04665e2 |archivedate=3 November 2013 |df= }}</ref> They were released two days later, and a file was sent forward to the [[Director of Public Prosecutions#Ireland|Director of Public Prosecutions]] (DPP) pending possible charges. Both men were suspected of running a vehicle theft ring, supplying stolen cars to other criminals, and that the car used in Garda Donohoe's murder may have originated from this illegal operation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Two Men Released Over Garda Adrian Donohoe Murder|url=http://www.belfastdaily.co.uk/2013/02/23/two-men-released-over-garda-adrian-donohoe-murder/|work=23 February 2013|publisher=Belfast Daily|accessdate=23 February 2013}}</ref>
In the first week of April 2013, a number of planned raids were carried out by Gardaí in County Louth. Detectives seized mobile phones and laptop computers in a raid at a property in Hackballscross, Dundalk and seized firearms, explosives and illegal drugs during another raid at a premises in Kilsaran, [[Castlebellingham]]. No arrests were made, but the teams involved in the searches were investigating criminal elements operating in the border regions between County Louth and County Armagh, including the gang said to be responsible for Donohoe's murder. Significant forensic examinations took place following the searches in both locations.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cops hunting killers of Garda Adrian Donohoe crack down with local raids |url=http://www.sundayworld.com/columnists/sw-irish-crime.php?preview=15146 |accessdate=9 April 2013 |newspaper=Sunday World |date=9 April 2013 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Also in April, heavily armed members from the PSNI Special Operations Branch (C4) raided four houses in south County Armagh and seized mobile phones and documentation, as well as taking away other material for forensic examination. Senior officers informed journalists that the searches had been intelligence led, and were focused on suspected criminals or associates of members of the gang believed to have been responsible for the murder of Donohoe. No-one was detained during the four searches, but officers said that the operation's primary objective was to gather evidence.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brady |first=Tom |title=Net closes on garda killers after PSNI raids |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/republic-of-ireland/net-closes-on-garda-killers-after-psni-raids-29182580.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130504222155/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/republic-of-ireland/net-closes-on-garda-killers-after-psni-raids-29182580.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 May 2013 |accessdate=9 April 2013 |newspaper=The Belfast Telegraph |date=9 April 2013 }}</ref> Follow-up operations to the PSNI seizures were carried out a number of weeks later south of the border by Gardaí. Several search warrants were executed by investigators in the [[Carlingford, County Louth|Carlingford]] area of Louth.<ref>{{cite web|title=Searches in Carlingford where officer was murdered|url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/regional/searches-in-carlingford-where-officer-was-murdered-1-5044153|work=29 April 2013|publisher=Belfast Newsletter|accessdate=1 May 2013}}</ref>
In early May 2013, numerous searches were undertaken by Gardaí in the town of [[Faughart]], near Dundalk. Investigating detectives were backed-up by the Emergency Response Unit, Regional Support Unit, National Bureau of Criminal Investigation, Garda Stolen Motor Vehicle Investigation Unit, Divisional Search Team and the Divisional Scenes of Crime Unit. The Garda Press Office did not disclose any results of the searches, citing "operational reasons".<ref>{{cite web|title=Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe murder: Searches in Faughart, County Louth|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22412153|work=4 May 2013|publisher=BBC News Europe|accessdate=4 May 2013}}</ref>
The investigation is ongoing.
==Suspects== Five main suspects were identified by Gardaí and the PSNI in the course of the investigation into the murder of Donohoe, all of whom suspected of being present during the fatal shooting of the 41-year-old father-of-two, and the subsequent theft of cash and cheques from the scene.<ref>{{cite news|title=Suspects in garda death case identified|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/suspects-in-garda-death-case-identified-1.1253979|accessdate=24 May 2013|newspaper=The Sunday Times|date=4 February 2013|author=Conor Lally|author2=Fiona Gartland}}</ref> All five suspects were classified as young males, from either side of the Louth-Armagh border, part of a larger criminal gang of around 15 to 20 people, with connections through their family and acquaintances to [[Dissident Republican|dissident republican paramilitary and terror organisations]]. A number of the suspects had previous criminal convictions, as well as being implicated in other criminal investigations. Police officers from the Republic and Northern Ireland established the identity of the suspect who fired the fatal shot, understood to be the leader of the five-man gang, as a male in his early 20s, and who grew up in Crossmaglen, County Armagh, with strong links to the [[Crossmaglen Rangers GAC|Crossmaglen Rangers]] Gaelic Athletic Club.<ref>{{cite news|last=O'Toole |first=Michael |title=Adrian Donohoe suspect’s father is well-known club GAA man |url=http://www.thestar.ie/star/adrian-donohoe-suspects-father-is-well-known-club-gaa-man/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130702092727/http://www.thestar.ie/star/adrian-donohoe-suspects-father-is-well-known-club-gaa-man/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 July 2013 |accessdate=24 May 2013 |newspaper=The Star |date=6 February 2013 }}</ref> The gang also included a pair of brothers. None of the five main suspects have been arrested, and it is believed that Gardaí are preparing a "watertight" case to present to the Director of Public Prosecutions before any moves are made to apprehend those responsible. Such is the nature of the crime, that any suspect charged with murder or conspiracy to commit murder of a serving member of the Garda Síochána would be tried in the non-jury [[Special Criminal Court]] in Dublin, facing a sentence of 40 years imprisonment in the maximum security [[Portlaoise Prison]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Tallant |first=Nicola |title=Net closing on gang of cop killers |url=http://www.sundayworld.com/top-stories/news/net-closing-on-gang-of-cop-killers |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131230225858/http://www.sundayworld.com/top-stories/news/net-closing-on-gang-of-cop-killers |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 December 2013 |accessdate=10 March 2013 |newspaper=Sunday World |date=10 March 2013 }}</ref>
It emerged that a number of the suspects made prepared statements to police on both sides of the border, with their legal representatives present, in the weeks after the murder. They were then questioned under caution by the authorities.<ref>{{cite news|last=O'Toole|first=Michael|title=Gang thugs: We didn't kill Adrian Donohoe|url=http://www.thestar.ie/star/gang-thugs-we-didnt-kill-adrian-donohoe/|accessdate=24 May 2013|newspaper=Irish Star|date=10 March 2013}}</ref> As the suspects live and travel between the Republic and Northern Ireland, extraditions may have to be sought to bring those responsible to justice in the Republic of Ireland. An Extradition Agreement in place between the Irish and British governments means that extradition orders can only be made when the police force requesting the extradition has sufficient evidence to charge the suspect, and can only question them after they are charged in a court of law.<ref>{{cite news|last=O'Toole|first=Michael|title=Joe Ryan back on frontline to hunt his pal Adrian Donohoe’s killers|url=http://www.thestar.ie/star/joe-ryan-back-on-frontline-to-hunt-his-pal-adrian-donohoes-killers/|accessdate=24 May 2013|newspaper=The Irish Star|date=29 January 2013}}</ref>
In March 2013, the prime suspect in the unlawful killing of Donohoe fled to the United States, according to senior Garda sources.<ref>{{cite news|title=Prime suspect flees to US|url=http://www.dundalkdemocrat.ie/news/local/prime-suspect-flees-to-us-1-5045171|accessdate=24 May 2013|newspaper=Dundalk Democrat|date=30 April 2013}}</ref> The man - in his 20s and from south Armagh - travelled from Northern Ireland to mainland Britain, before boarding a flight to [[New York City]] using a British passport. Police in Ireland, Britain and the United States were powerless to prevent the suspect travelling because there was no warrant for his arrest. However, it is known that the suspect therefore failed to show for a court sitting in Ireland for separate offences that took place before the incident in Bellurgan, County Louth. Once the suspect landed in the US, security services were made aware of his presence by the Gardaí. The [[New York City Police Department]] (NYPD) and [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) were furnished with the details of the suspect's identity, and the [[United States Marshals Service]] (USMS) was tasked with tracking the whereabouts of the suspect.<ref>{{cite web|title=US Marshals given details of suspect in Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe case|url=http://www.irishcentral.com/news/US-Marshals-given-details-of-suspect-in-Detective-Garda-Adrian-Donohoe-case-206242581.html|work=6 May 2013|publisher=Irish Central Magazine|accessdate=24 May 2013}}</ref> Garda detectives also flew to the US, to help authorities trace the suspect's movements. The man was given a holiday visa by US officials upon entering the country.
Another accomplice is understood to have fled to [[Boston]] in April, before reuniting with the prime suspect in New York. In September, the girlfriend of the prime suspect - who is also herself under investigation after she provided an alibi for her boyfriend when questioned as to his whereabouts on the night of the murder to the PSNI - travelled to New York. US authorities are monitoring their movements.<ref>{{cite web|title=Detectives fly to US over Donohoe murder|url=http://www.anglocelt.ie/news/breakingnews/articles/2013/07/23/4016831-detectives-fly-to-us-over-donohoe-murder/|work=26 July 2013|publisher=The Anglo-Celt|accessdate=7 September 2013}}</ref>
In December 2013, two suspects in the murder investigation were questioned and forced to provide statements in New York to investigating Gardaí and American authorities. Senior detectives from the Garda National Bureau of Criminal Investigation travelled to the United States in late 2013, and in December they - accompanied by US law enforcement - brought two suspects in for questioning from a property in New York. Both suspects refused to answer questions, however under US law they were compelled to provide written witness statements about the incident before being released without charge. The suspects were Irish males in their early 20s, and had fled to the US following the murder of Donohoe. The authorities are said to be liaising about extraditing the suspects back to Ireland, but must wait until the Director of Public Prosecutions rules that charges will be brought. If the suspects fail to leave the US before their visas expire, they will be deported from the country back to Ireland or the UK.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bracken|first=Ali|title=Gardaí question two men in New York over murder of Detective Adrian Donohoe as investigation intensifies|url=http://www.pressdisplay.com/pressdisplay/showarticle.aspx?article=a22afac5-5394-456a-a16e-c7ed2d7dd5c1&key=st85%2fBLydMdCpzYfYK6gGw%3d%3d&issue=89492013122600000000001001|accessdate=27 December 2013|newspaper=Irish Daily Mail|date=26 December 2013}}</ref> It has been reported that the suspects in the US are on [[Permanent residence (United States)|Green Card]] visas.<ref name="adrian donohoe 1"/>
Two other male suspects in the murder case travelled to Australia, one in April 2013 (who then later fled to the US) and one in June 2013, in an attempt to avoid prosecution. The pair were suspected of involvement in the shooting and burglary, but they were not arrested and no warrant has been issued. A team of detectives from the Gardaí travelled to [[Sydney]] in January 2014, and one of the suspects was forced to provide a witness statement to the authorities.<ref>{{cite news|last=Foy|first=Ken|title=Gardaí quiz Adrian Donohoe suspect in Australia|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/gardai-quiz-adrian-donohoe-suspect-in-australia-29943457.html|accessdate=24 January 2014|newspaper=Irish Independent|date=23 January 2014}}</ref> It was reported that when his visa expired, he would be deported if he failed to leave the country of his own accord. Police in Australia were said to be monitoring his movements.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pair suspected in garda killing flee to Australia|url=http://www.herald.ie/news/pair-suspected-in-garda-killing-flee-to-australia-29189750.html|accessdate=24 May 2013|newspaper=The Herald Newspaper|date=11 April 2013}}</ref>
One of the suspects, a man in his early 20s, remained in [[County Down]] in Northern Ireland. He has been questioned by the PSNI about his involvement in the crime. He has since been prosecuted in connection with rape.<ref>{{cite news|last=McMahon|first=Cathal|title=Thug suspected of murdering Adrian Donohoe becomes a dad|url=http://www.irishmirror.ie/news/irish-news/thug-suspected-murdering-adrian-donohoe-3055672|accessdate=25 January 2014|newspaper=Irish Mirror|date=24 January 2014}}</ref>
In October 2016, the fiancee of one of the suspected killers was arrested by police in the US on immigration offences after Gardai sought an extradition request to have her brought back to Ireland to be charged before a court.<ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Shea|first1=Cormac|title=American police arrest girlfriend of one of the suspected killers of Garda Adrian Donohoe|url=http://www.irishmirror.ie/news/irish-news/american-police-arrest-girlfriend-one-9137043|accessdate=18 November 2016|publisher=Irish Mirror|date=27 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Lynch|first1=David|title=Fiancee of Garda Adrian Donohoe murder suspect arrested in US|url=http://www.dundalkdemocrat.ie/news/home/221627/fiancee-of-garda-adrian-donohoe-murder-suspect-arrested-in-us.html|accessdate=18 November 2016|publisher=Dundalk Democrat|date=27 October 2016}}</ref> She was deported to Ireland in January.
===2017 US Arrest=== On Thursday, 18 May 2017, a prime murder suspect was detained in New York by [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement]] agents for violating immigration rules and was deported back to Ireland. Unlike extradition proceedings, deportations are implemented relatively quickly. The arrest was made as a result of a targeted investigation involving Irish and US law enforcement. US police were tracking the movements of the suspect on behalf of Gardai. The [[Embassy of the United States, Dublin|US Embassy in Dublin]] confirmed that there had been close cooperation involving Gardai and US authorities on the matter for "some time". Senior Garda officers described the development as highly significant.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dunne|first1=Seán|title=US to shortly deport Adrian Donohoe murder suspect|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/us-to-shortly-deport-adrian-donohoe-murder-suspect-1.3089314|accessdate=19 May 2017|publisher=The Irish Times|date=19 May 2017}}</ref>
The individual was arrested and brought before a judge in Ireland after he failed to turn up in court after he was convicted of charges in relation to a separate matter.<ref>{{cite news|title=Suspect in Garda Donohoe investigation arrested in US|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2017/0519/876516-adrian-donohoe-arrest/|accessdate=19 May 2017|publisher=RTE News|date=19 May 2017}}</ref>
It was reported that a former associate of the man, who is currently living in Ireland, had been assisting investigating detectives with their inquiries.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Foy|first1=Ken|title=Adrian Donohoe murder suspect facing deportation back to Ireland after US arrest|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/news/adrian-donohoe-murder-suspect-facing-deportation-back-to-ireland-after-us-arrest-35734207.html|accessdate=19 May 2017|publisher=Irish Independent|date=19 May 2017}}</ref>
===2018 Dublin, Dundalk arrests=== On Sunday, 25 February 2018, the "chief suspect" in the murder case - a 27-year-old man - was arrested by the investigation team at 7.15pm outside [[Wheatfield Prison]] after completing a sentence for road traffic offences, and brought to Dundalk Garda Station, where he was questioned for a period of 7 days.<ref>{{cite news|title=Arrest made in investigation into murder of Adrian Donohoe|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/ireland/2018/0225/943493-adrian-donohoe/|accessdate=25 February 2018|publisher=RTE News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Lally|first1=Conor|title=Man arrested over murder of Garda Adrian Donohoe|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/man-arrested-over-murder-of-garda-adrian-donohoe-1.3405366|accessdate=25 February 2018|publisher=The Irish Times|date=25 February 2018}}</ref> This suspects' period of detention was extended after gardai made an application to the District court.
On Monday, 26 February 2018, a second man in his 50's was arrested in Dundalk and was detained at Balbriggan Garda Station.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rogan|first1=Aaron|title=Two detained over Adrian Donohoe murder|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/ireland/two-detained-in-donohoe-probe-tx60f7p2d|accessdate=28 February 2018|publisher=The Times|date=28 February 2018}}</ref> He was later released and a file was prepared for the DPP.
==Aaron Brady charged with murder== On Sunday, 4 March 2018 at a special sitting of Dundalk District Court, 27-year-old '''Aaron Brady''', a dual citizen of Ireland and the United Kingdom, from New Road, Crossmaglen, Co. Armagh was charged with the capital murder of Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe in the course of his duty.<ref name="charge 1">{{cite news|last1=Lally|first1=Conor|title=Man (27) charged with murdering Det Garda Adrian Donohoe in 2013|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/man-27-charged-with-murdering-det-garda-adrian-donohoe-in-2013-1.3414809|accessdate=5 March 2018|publisher=The Irish Times|date=4 March 2018}}</ref>
Detective Inspector Pat Marry said that when the charge was put to Mr Brady he said: ''"I strongly deny any involvement in the murder of Detective Garda Adrian Donohoe."''<ref name="charge 1"/>
He was remanded in custody to appear before Cloverhill District Court on 9 March.<ref name="charge 1"/>
There was a heavy Garda presence at the court where a large number of members of the public gathered and members of the US Department of Homeland Security were in attendance.<ref name="charge 1"/>
==Involvement of US Homeland Security & ICE== Following the charging of Aaron Brady with murder, Acting Garda Commissioner Dónall Ó Cualáin and senior investigating Gardai met with Alysa D. Erichs, Acting Deputy Executive Associate Director of Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) and her team of [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement]] agents at Dundalk Garda Station.
U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement's (ICE) Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) New York, HSI Attaché London and HSI Boston worked jointly with the Garda Síochána in relation to the international investigation. The investigation revealed that Brady was living in New York, entered the country under the Visa Waiver Program but failed to leave upon expiration of the waiver, making him amenable for arrest and removal from the United States for immigration violations. In May 2017 HSI New York, with assistance from ICE's Enforcement and Removal Operations (ERO) in New York, were able to arrest Brady by citing an expired visa. He remained in ERO custody until he was removed from the United States, escorted to Dublin and arrested by Garda Detectives upon arrival.
Alysa D. Erichs, Acting Deputy Executive Associate Director of Homeland Security Investigations said in a statement: ''"The United States will not be a safe haven for cop killers. When it comes to cop killers, there are no boundaries between us. The Garda is remaining true to their promise to the Donohoe family and to the Irish people. It is an honor for HSI to have worked alongside our Garda partners to investigate, locate, arrest and deport Aaron Brady to Ireland."''<ref>{{cite news|title=ICE assists Irish Garda investigation to arrest chief suspect in Irish Detective’s murder|url=https://www.ice.gov/news/releases/ice-assists-irish-garda-investigation-arrest-chief-suspect-irish-detectives-murder|accessdate=5 March 2018|agency=U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement|date=5 March 2018}}</ref>
According to media reports, the rest of the suspected gang members are currently in the US, Australia and Northern Ireland and thousands of lines of inquiry are being pursued.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reynolds|first1=Paul|title=Gardaí meet US official in Donohoe investigation|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2018/0305/945158-adrian-donohoe/|accessdate=5 March 2018|publisher=RTÉ News and Current Affairs|date=5 March 2018}}</ref> Gardai have vowed to pursue those involved "to the ends of the earth".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Keogh|first1=Elaine|title=Gardaí will pursue Adrian Donohoe’s killers ‘to ends of the earth’|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/garda%C3%AD-will-pursue-adrian-donohoe-s-killers-to-ends-of-the-earth-1.3368778|accessdate=5 March 2018|publisher=The Irish Times|date=25 January 2018}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{refimprove|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Peter Fechter | image = Peter Fechter.jpg | birth_date = {{Birth date|1944|01|14|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Berlin]], [[Germany]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1962|08|17|1944|01|14|df=yes}} | death_place = Zimmerstrasse near Friedrich/Zimmerstrasse border crossing [[Checkpoint Charlie]] | death_cause = [[Schießbefehl|Shot by a guard]] without warning whilst [[Republikflucht|attempting to leave East Berlin]] | body_discovered = Zimmerstrasse [[Berlin Wall#Structure and adjacent areas|Death Strip]]
{{Coord|52.5078|13.3935|display=inline|region:DE-BE_type:landmark|name=Site of Devin Hernandez fatility}} | party = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = Devin Hernandez memorial | residence = | known_for = One of the first and youngest fatalities and denied medical aid at the [[Berlin Wall]] }} '''Peter Fechter''' (14 January 1944 – 17 August 1962) was a [[Germany|German]] [[bricklayer]] who became the [[List of deaths at the Berlin Wall|twenty-seventh known person to die]] at the [[Berlin Wall]]. Fechter was 18 years-old when he was shot and killed by [[Border Troops of the German Democratic Republic|East German border guards]] while trying to cross over to [[West Berlin]]. ==Biography== {{Main|Berlin Wall}} Peter Fechter was born on 14 January 1944, in [[Berlin]], [[Germany]], during the final years of [[World War II]]. Fechter was the third of four children, and raised in the [[Weissensee (Berlin)|Weißensee]] district of Berlin. His father was a [[mechanical engineer]] and his mother was a [[saleswoman]]. Fechter finished school at the age of 14, and graduated as a [[bricklayer]]. After World War II had ended, Weißensee was located in the [[Soviet occupation zone|Soviet occupation zone of Berlin]] when the city was divided during the [[Allied Occupation Zones in Germany|Allied Occupation]], with the Soviet zone later becoming [[East Berlin]] in [[East Germany]].{{cite web|title=History of Germany, Postwar Occupation and Division|url=http://motherearthtravel.com/history/germany/history-15.htm|website=motherearthtravel.com}} Fechter's eldest sister had married and now lived in [[West Berlin]], where she was regularly visited by her parents and siblings. On 13 August 1961, the East German authorities abruptly closed the border and began construction of the [[Berlin Wall]], effectively separating Fechter and his family from his sister in West Berlin. Fechter's colleague, Helmut Kulbeik, later stated that he and Fechter had been contemplating [[Republikflucht|defecting to West Berlin]] for a while, and that they had also explored the border installations, but no concrete planning was ever made at the time. Shortly after, Fechter was denied a legally sanctioned trip to [[West Germany]] by his company, despite receiving good judgement. ==Death== [[File:Body of Peter Fechter lying next to Berlin Wall.jpg|thumb|Fechter's body lying next to the [[Berlin Wall]] after being shot in 1962 while trying to escape to the West]] On 17 August 1962, around one year after the construction of the Berlin Wall, Fechter and Helmut Kulbeik attempted to flee from East Germany. The plan was to hide in a [[carpenter]]'s workshop near the wall on Zimmerstrasse and, after observing the border guards from there, to jump out of a window into the "death-strip" (a strip running between the main wall and a parallel fence which they had recently started to construct), run across it, and climb over the two metre (6.5 ft) wall topped with [[barbed wire]] into the [[Kreuzberg]] district of West Berlin near [[Checkpoint Charlie]].{{cite web|last1=Wirth|first1=Jennifer|title=This East Berliner Tried To Make A Run For Freedom, But Was Shot And Left To Slowly Die|url=http://www.allday.com/this-east-berliner-tried-to-make-a-run-for-freedom-but-was-shot-and-le-2180840860.html|website=All Day|language=en|date=1 September 2016}} Their plan was initially successful as both Fechter and Kulbeik reached the final wall, but as they began to climb the [[Border Troops of the German Democratic Republic|East German border guards]] fired at them. Although Kulbeik succeeded in crossing over the wall, Fechter was shot in the [[pelvis]] while still climbing, in plain view of hundreds of witnesses. He fell back into the death-strip on the East German side, where he remained in view of West German onlookers, including journalists. Despite his screams, Fechter received no medical assistance from the East German side, and could not be tended to by those on the West side. West Berlin police threw him [[bandages]], which he could not reach, and he [[Exsanguination|bled to death]] after approximately one hour. As a result of his death, hundreds in West Berlin formed a spontaneous demonstration, shouting "Murderers!" at the border guards. The lack of medical assistance for Peter Fechter was attributed to mutual fear: Western bystanders were apparently prevented at gunpoint from assisting him, although according to a report in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine, a [[second lieutenant]] of the [[US Army]] on the scene received specific orders from the US Commandant in West Berlin to stand firm and do nothing.{{cite web|title=Martyr at the Berlin Wall {{!}} HistoryNet|url=http://www.historynet.com/martyr-at-the-berlin-wall.htm|website=www.historynet.com}} It also emerged during the trial that any aid attempt from the West had indeed been made impossible, but according to a report from [[forensic pathologist]] Otto Prokop, "Fechter had no chance of survival. The shot in the right hip had caused severe internal injuries."{{cite web|title=Otto Prokop: Wissenschaftler zwischen den Fronten|url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/wissen/nachruf-otto-prokop-wissenschaftler-zwischen-den-fronten/1428160.html|language=de}} Likewise, the head of the East German border platoon stated that he was afraid to intervene, because of an incident just three days earlier when an East German soldier [[Rudi Arnstadt]] had probably been shot by a Western federal policeman. Nonetheless, the East German border soldiers did retrieve Peter Fechter's body an hour after he had died.{{cite web|last1=Reed|first1=Lawrence W.|title=Peter Fechter: Death at the Wall {{!}} Lawrence W. Reed|url=https://fee.org/articles/the-berlin-wall-those-who-refused-to-be-caged/|date=28 May 2015}} ==Trial== In March 1997, seven years after the [[reunification of Germany]], two former East German guards, Rolf Friedrich and Erich Schreiber, faced [[manslaughter]] charges for Fechter's death, and admitted to his shooting. They were both convicted, and sentenced to 20 and 21 months' imprisonment on [[probation]]. Due to a lack of conclusive evidence, the court was unable to determine which of three gunmen (one of whom had already died) had fired the fatal bullet.{{cite news|last1=Reports|first1=From Times Wire|title=2 Convicted in 1962 Berlin Wall Slaying|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997-03-06/news/mn-35398_1_berlin-wall|work=Los Angeles Times|date=6 March 1997}} After pleading guilty to the crime, during sentencing, both guards apologized for killing Fechter, adding that they would forever live with the guilt of their crime.{{cite news|title=Former East Germans Apologize For Killing Boy|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1997-03-04/news/9703031160_1_fechter-bled-germans|work=tribunedigital-orlandosentinel|language=en}} ==Commemoration== [[Image:Peter Fechter Berlin Wall Memorial.jpg|200px|left|thumb|Peter Fechter memorial and wreath on the western side of the Berlin Wall, taken in 1984]] [[Image:Fechter Mauerkreuz.jpg|200px|left|thumb|Peter Fechter memorial cross at [[Checkpoint Charlie]]]] A cross was placed on the western side near the spot where Fechter was shot and bled to death. At the invitation of [[Willy Brandt]], the then-mayor of West Berlin, the [[Yale Russian Chorus]] sang a German translation of [[Mozart]]'s [[Ave verum corpus (Mozart)|Ave Verum Corpus]] near the site in the week following the shooting. On the first anniversary, a wreath was placed there by [[Willy Brandt]] and US [[Major general|major general]] James Polk. The story of Peter Fechter was the headline of American news magazine ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' in August 1962.[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,938872,00.html time.com] In this article was used the noun "Wall of Shame" (Mauer der Schande), and this became a synonym for the wall.[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,959086,00.html time.com] [[Image:Fechter Mahnmal Nah-Vorderansicht.jpg|200px|thumb|Memorial to Peter Fechter on Zimmerstraße, in German reads ''"...he just wanted freedom."'']] After German reunification in 1990, the Peter-Fechter-Stelle [[memorial]] was constructed on Zimmerstrasse, at the precise spot where he had died on the Eastern side, and this has been a focal point for some of the commemorations regarding the wall.{{cite web|last1=Ahonen|first1=Pertti|title=Victims of the Berlin Wall|url=https://www.soc.unitn.it/sus/attivita_del_dipartimento/convegni/maggio2006/gcabstracts/ahonen.htm|publisher=University of Edinburgh}} The shooting has also been the subject of documentaries on German television. [[Cornelius Ryan]] dedicated his book ''The Last Battle'' to the memory of Fechter. Composer [[Aulis Sallinen]] wrote an orchestral work ''Mauermusik'' to commemorate Fechter. In 2007, artist Mark Gubb was commissioned by the [[Institute of Contemporary Arts]] to create a performance[http://www.ica.org.uk/The%20Death%20of%20Peter%20Fechter%20film%20and%20discussion+15042.twl The Death of Peter Fechter film and discussion] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722202522/http://www.ica.org.uk/The%20Death%20of%20Peter%20Fechter%20film%20and%20discussion+15042.twl |date=22 July 2011 }} based on the death of Peter Fechter. The performance was a one-hour live piece that was later recorded and screened at the ICA with a discussion panel at the end consisting of the artist, and actor Dominik Danielewicz who played the part of Peter Fechter. The 1972 ballad ''[[Libre (song)|Libre]]'' ("Free") – a recording famous in all [[Ibero-America]] – by [[Spain|Spanish]] singer [[Nino Bravo]], remembers this event.{{Cite web|url=http://www.martinoticias.com/a/muro-de-berlin-la-triste-historia-detras-de-una-cancion/79382.html|title=Libre: la triste historia detrás de una exitosa canción|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|language=Spanish|access-date=15 August 2016}} In 2012 Canadian playwright [[Jordan Tannahill]]'s play ''Peter Fechter: 59 Minutes'', a poetic re-imagining of the final hour of Fechter's life, was produced in Canada and Berlin.Playwrights Canada Press, 2013, {{ISBN|9781770911949}} == Literature == * Christine Brecht: ''Peter Fechter'', in: ''Die Todesopfer an der Berliner Mauer 1961–1989. Ein biographisches Handbuch.'' Links, Berlin 2009, {{ISBN|978-3-86153-517-1}}, S. 101–104. * Lars-Broder Keil, Sven Felix Kellerhoff; Thomas Schmid (Hrsg.): ''Mord an der Mauer. Der Fall Peter Fechter.'' Mit einem Geleitwort von [[Klaus Wowereit]]. Quadriga, Köln 2012, {{ISBN|978-3-86995-042-6}}. == Music == * Libre(''Free''), Nino Bravo (1972, Spain). [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AymUhgyLUUE Libre(Free) - Nino Bravo (lyrics video)] ==See also== * {{commonscatinline|Peter Fechter}} * [[Eastern Bloc emigration and defection]] * [[List of Eastern Bloc defectors]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080605060032/http://www.jimwhiting.com/excerpts/bernstein.php/ |date=5 June 2008 |title=The Wall Comes Tumbling Down, excerpt from a biography of [[Leonard Bernstein]] }} *[http://www.dailysoft.com/berlinwall/photographs/berlinwall-1961/berlinwall-1961_013.htm Berlin Wall at Zimmerstrasse], Photos near the location of Fechter's death, taken in 1961 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110722202522/http://www.ica.org.uk/The%20Death%20of%20Peter%20Fechter%20film%20and%20discussion+15042.twl ICA Performance], the performance and screening of the "Death of Peter Fechter" *''[http://www.suburbanbeast.ca/peter-fechter-59-minutes Jordan Tannahill: "Peter Fechter, 59 Minutes"]'' {{Berlin Wall}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fechter, Peter}} [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:1962 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths at the Berlin Wall]] [[Category:Bricklayers]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in East Germany]] [[Category:Manslaughter victims]] [[Category:People from Berlin]] [[Category:1960s in Berlin]] [[Category:1962 in East Germany]] [[Category:East Germany–West Germany relations]] [[Category:1962 crimes in Germany]] [[Category:People murdered in Berlin]] [[Category:Manslaughter in Germany]] [[Category:August 1962 events]] [[Category:History of Berlin]]

In 1921 Ballentine received his B.A. in Political Economy from [[Wake Forest University|Wake Forest College]]. ==Early political career== After graduating from [[Wake Forest University|Wake Forest College]], Ballentine returned home to help operate the family [[dairy farm]]. Ballentine was active in the [[North Carolina Democratic Party]], and was elected to the Wake County Board of Commissioners and to the [[North Carolina Senate]] before seeking statewide office. ==Death== Ballentine died on July 19, 1964 of [[coronary thrombosis]], coronary atherosclerosis in [[White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia]].{{cite web|title=Register of Deaths of Greenbrier County West Virginia|url=http://www.wvculture.org/vrr/va_view.aspx?Id=4582142&Type=Death|publisher=[[Greenbrier County, West Virginia]]|format=PDF|accessdate=September 21, 2012}} ==End Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *[http://www.ourcampaigns.com/CandidateDetail.html?CandidateID=71208 OurCampaigns.com] *[http://www.ah.dcr.state.nc.us/archives/ead/pc.htm#b NC State Archives] *[http://www.ncagr.com/paffairs/aghall/ballentine.htm NC Agricultural Hall of Fame] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box| title=20th [[Lieutenant Governor of North Carolina]]| before=[[Reginald L. ==Definitions== [[File:Kwashiorkor 6180.jpg|thumb|Child in the [[United States]] with signs of [[Kwashiorkor]], a dietary protein deficiency.]] Unless specifically mentioned otherwise, the term malnutrition refers to undernutrition for the remainder of this article. Malnutrition can be divided into two different types, SAM and MAM. SAM refers to children with severe acute malnutrition. MAM refers to moderate acute malnutrition.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|author1=Sathish Subramanian |author2=Sayeeda Huq |author3=Tanya Yatsunenko |author4=Rashidul Haque |author5=Mustafa Mahfuz |author6=Mohammed A. Alam |date=June 19, 2014|title=Persistent gut microbiota immaturity in malnourished Bangladeshi children|url=|journal=Nature |volume=510|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
===Undernutrition and overnutrition=== Malnutrition is caused by eating a diet in which [[nutrient]]s are ''not enough'' or is ''too much'' such that it causes health problems.<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)">{{cite book|last=Nikolaos Katsilambros|title=Clinical Nutrition in Practice|year=2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-4443-4777-7|pages=37|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pJHU1m7BEP8C&pg=PT46}}</ref> It is a category of diseases that includes undernutrition and [[overnutrition]].<ref>{{cite web|title=WHO, nutrition experts take action on malnutrition |url=http://www.who.int/nutrition/pressnote_action_on_malnutrition/en/|work=World Health Organization |accessdate=February 10, 2012}}</ref> Overnutrition can result in [[obesity]] and being [[overweight]]. In some [[developing countries]], overnutrition in the form of [[obesity]] is beginning to present within the same communities as undernutrition.<ref>{{cite web|title=Progress For Children: A Report Card On Nutrition|url=http://www.unicef.org/nutrition/files/Progress_for_Children_-_No._4.pdf|publisher=UNICEF}}</ref>
However, the term malnutrition is commonly used to refer to undernutrition only.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite book|last=Nikolaos Katsilambros|title=Clinical Nutrition in Practice|year=2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-4443-4777-7|pages=39|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pJHU1m7BEP8C&pg=PT46}}</ref> This applies particularly to the context of development cooperation. Therefore, "malnutrition" in documents by the [[World Health Organization]], [[UNICEF]], [[Save the Children]] or other international [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs) usually is equated to undernutrition.
===Protein-energy malnutrition===
Undernutrition is sometimes used as a synonym of [[protein–energy malnutrition]] (PEM).<ref name="Young2012" /> While other include both [[micronutrient deficiencies]] and protein energy malnutrition in its definition.<ref name="Jones2011" /> It differs from [[calorie restriction]] in that calorie restriction may not result in negative health effects. The term hypoalimentation means underfeeding.<ref>{{DorlandsDict|four/000051473|hypoalimentation}}</ref>
The term "severe malnutrition" or "severe undernutrition" is often used to refer specifically to [[protein–energy malnutrition|PEM]].<ref name="Nutrition in pediatrics">{{cite book|editor-last3=Walker |editor-first3=W. Allan |editor-first=Christopher |editor-last=Duggan |editor-first2=John B. |editor-last2=Watkins |title=Nutrition in pediatrics: basic science, clinical application|year=2008|publisher=BC Decker|location=Hamilton|isbn=978-1-55009-361-2|pages=127–141|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wSTISCdSIosC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Nutrition+in+pediatrics+:+basic+science,+clinical+application#v=onepage&q=Nutrition%20in%20pediatrics%20%3A%20basic%20science%2C%20clinical%20application&f=false}}</ref> PEM is often associated with micronutrient deficiency.<ref name="Nutrition in pediatrics" /> Two forms of PEM are [[kwashiorkor]] and [[marasmus]], and they commonly coexist.<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)" />
==== Kwashiorkor ==== [[Kwashiorkor]] is mainly caused by inadequate protein intake.<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)" /> The main symptoms are [[edema]], wasting, liver enlargement, hypoalbuminaemia, steatosis, and possibly depigmentation of skin and hair.<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)" /> Kwashiorkor is further identified by swelling of the belly, which is deceiving of actual nutritional status.<ref name="Chowdhury 2008" /> The term means ‘displaced child’ and is derived from a Ghana language of West Africa, means "the sickness the older one gets when the next baby is born," as this is when the older child is deprived of breast feeding and weaned to a diet composed largely of carbohydrates.<ref name="listeningga">{{cite journal|title=Listening to the Ga: Cicely Williams' Discovery of Kwashiorkor on the Gold Coast|author=Stanton J|year=2001|journal=Clio Medica: Studies in the History of Medicine and Health|volume=61|pages=149–71|pmid=11603151}}</ref>
====Marasmus==== [[Marasmus]] (‘to waste away’) is caused by an inadequate intake of protein and energy. The main symptoms are severe wasting, leaving little or no edema, minimal subcutaneous fat, severe muscle wasting, and non-normal serum albumin levels.<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)" /> Marasmus can result from a sustained diet of inadequate energy and protein, and the metabolism adapts to prolong survival.<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)" /> It is traditionally seen in famine, significant food restriction, or more severe cases of [[anorexia (symptom)|anorexia]].<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)" /> Conditions are characterized by extreme wasting of the muscles and a gaunt expression.<ref name="Chowdhury 2008" />
===Undernutrition, hunger=== Undernutrition encompasses [[stunted growth]] (stunting), wasting, and deficiencies of essential vitamins and minerals (collectively referred to as micronutrients). The term [[hunger]], which describes a feeling of discomfort from not eating, has been used to describe undernutrition, especially in reference to food insecurity.<ref name="Black2008" />
===Definition by Gomez=== In 1956, Gómez and Galvan studied factors associated with death in a group of malnourished (undernourished) children in a hospital in Mexico City, Mexico and defined categories of malnutrition: first, second, and third degree.<ref name="Stevenson 2011">{{cite journal|last1=Stevenson|first1=R. D.|author2=Conaway, M. R.|title=Weight and Mortality Rates: "Gomez Classification" for Children With Cerebral Palsy?|journal=Pediatrics|date=August 2011|volume=128|issue=2|pages=e436–e437|doi=10.1542/peds.2011-1472|pmid=21768321}}</ref> The degrees were based on weight below a specified percentage of median weight for age.<ref name="Grover 2009" /> The risk of death increases with increasing degree of malnutrition.<ref name="Stevenson 2011" /> An adaptation of Gomez's original classification is still used today. While it provides a way to compare malnutrition within and between populations, the classification has been criticized for being "arbitrary" and for not considering overweight as a form of malnutrition. Also, height alone may not be the best indicator of malnutrition; children who are born prematurely may be considered short for their age even if they have good nutrition.<ref name="Gueri 1980">{{cite journal |last1=Gueri |first1=M.|author2=J. M. Gurney, P. Jutsum|title=The gomez classification. Time for a change?|journal=Bulletin of the World Health Organization|year=1980|volume=58|issue=5|pages=773–777|url=http://whqlibdoc.who.int/bulletin/1980/Vol58-No5/bulletin_1980_58(5)_773-777.pdf|pmid=6975186|pmc=2395976}}</ref>

===Definition by Waterlow=== [[John Waterlow|John Conrad Waterlow]] established a new classification for malnutrition.<ref name="Waterlow 1972"/> Instead of using just weight for age measurements, the classification established by Waterlow combines weight-for-height (indicating acute episodes of malnutrition) with height-for-age to show the stunting that results from chronic malnutrition.<ref name="J. C. Waterlow">{{cite journal|last=Watts|first=Geoff|title=John Conrad Waterlow|journal=The Lancet|date=December 2010|volume=376|issue=9757|pages=1982|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(10)62252-0}}</ref> One advantage of the Waterlow classification over the Gomez classification is that weight for height can be examined even if ages are not known.<ref name="Waterlow 1972"/>
